Ord. 1660, 12-8-2015; Ord. 1739, 2-12-2019)
   C.   Payment Of Fees:
      1.   All of the fees for licenses in subsection B of this section shall
be paid annually on or before July 1 of each year. (1996 Code § 3-27; amd. 2010
Code)
      2.   License fees shall be paid to the City Clerk and accompanied by
renewal application on a form provided by the City Clerk. Those filing
applications between the months of January and June shall be charged one-half
(1/2) of the annual fee at the time of filing.
   D.   Disposition Of Fees; Refunds: The City Clerk shall turn over such fees
to the City Treasurer. If the license is granted, then the fee shall be
deposited by the City Treasurer in the General Corporate Fund of the City; if
the license is denied, the fee, or so much thereof as has been paid, shall be
returned to the applicant. (1996 Code § 3-28; amd. 2010 Code)
4-2-8: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Each applicant for a license required by this chapter shall file with the
application a bond in the penal sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), with
good and sufficient sureties to be approved by the Mayor, conditioned upon the
true and faithful compliance by the licensee with all the provisions of this
chapter, the laws of the State and of the United States relating to alcoholic
liquors and for the payment of all fees for the full period for which the
license is issued, together with all fines which may be assessed against the
licensee by reason of having violated any of the provisions of this chapter.
The sureties on the bond, if individuals, shall be residents of the State over
the age of twenty one (21) years and at least one of them a resident of the
County. The sureties shall be owners in fee of real estate located in the
County of the aggregate value of double the amount of the bond, over and above
all exemptions and encumbrances. If a corporate surety executes the bond, it
shall be authorized to do business in the State. (1996 Code § 3-29; amd. 2010
Code)
4-2-9: CONTENTS OF LICENSE:
Each license issued pursuant to this chapter shall state the date of issuance
and the expiration thereof, the name and address of the licensee or, in case of
a partnership, association or corporation, the names and addresses of all the
partners, members or stockholders thereof, the location and description of the
premises for which it is granted and the class to which it belongs, and shall
be signed by the Mayor as Liquor Control Commissioner. (1996 Code § 3-30; amd.
2010 Code)
4-2-10: EXPIRATION OF LICENSE:
Each license issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire on June 30 next
following its issuance. (1996 Code § 3-34)
4-2-11: CLASSES OF LICENSES:
Licenses are hereby divided into the following classes: (Ord. 1660, 12-8-2015)
   A.   Class A License: For the sale at retail of beer and wine for
consumption on the premises where sold, or in original packages or containers
for consumption off said premises.
   B.   Class B License: For sale at retail of alcoholic liquor, including beer
and wine, not for consumption on the premises where sold, and only in original
packages or containers; no such package or container to contain less than eight
(8) fluid ounces of such liquor.
   C.   Class C License: For sale at retail of alcoholic liquor, including beer
and wine, for consumption on the premises where sold, or in original package or
container for consumption off said premises.
   D.   Class D License: For sale of alcoholic liquor, including beer and wine,
on premises at clubs. (1996 Code § 3-23; amd. 2010 Code)
   E.   Class E License: For sale at retail of beer and wine in original
packages or containers for consumption off said premises by convenience stores
whose principal business is not the sale of alcoholic liquor. No signs
advertising the sale or availability of alcoholic beverages may be placed on
the exterior of the property except on permanent advertising marquees that are
used for general advertisement of products. No banners or flags or other
attention getting devices such as flashing lights, etc., are allowed. Beer and
wine may be displayed on the interior of said establishment, but only in such a
way that it would be separate from the other items. If the convenience store is
open twenty four (24) hours every day, said beer and wine must be locked up
during nonsale hours as indicated within this chapter. (Ord. 1230, 5-15-1998;
amd. 2010 Code)
   F.   Class F License: A temporary license for a period not to exceed seventy
two (72) hours for the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor, including beer and
wine, for consumption on the premises where sold, or in the original package or
container for consumption off the premises by a nonprofit corporation or group
or charitable association. (Ord. 1400, 5-27-2003; amd. 2010 Code)
   G.   Class G License: For sale at retail of beer and wine for consumption on
the premises where sold. (2010 Code)
   H.   Class H License: A license for a period not to exceed one year for the
sale at retail of wine at a periodically held farmers' and artisans' market, in
the original packages or containers for consumption off the premises of the
market. Sampling or tasting of the wine shall be allowed. There shall be no
application fee for this license. (Ord. 1525, 10-7-2008; amd. 2010 Code)
   I.   Class I License: A license for a period not to exceed seventy two (72)
hours for the sampling or tasting of wine and beer at a special event or events
and the sale at retail of the sampled wine and beer in the original packages or
containers for consumption off the premises. There shall be no application fee
for this license. (Ord. 1525, 10-7-2008)
   J.   Class J License: Authorizes the retail sale and consumption of
alcoholic liquor within the building located on the premises, provided the
licensed premises also has, locates, maintains and lawfully operates video
gaming terminals 1  within the Class J licensed establishment, pursuant to and
in accordance with the requirements of chapter 8 of this title. The issuance of
Class J licenses shall be subject to the following limitations:
      1.   The holder of a Class J license may not exceed the time and hour
limits as established in section
4-2-17 of this chapter.
      2.   The annual licensing fee may be refunded only if the State gaming
license is denied, less retention of a one hundred twenty five dollar ($125.00)
administrative fee; otherwise, this fee shall not be refundable nor prorated.
      3.   The holder of a Class J license must provide at least one
handicapped-accessible bathroom constructed in compliance with the requirements
of the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA compliant) exclusively
within the space occupied by said Class J licensee, and comply with all
Illinois laws with regard to the same.
      4.   No person, entity or establishment shall be eligible to hold a Class
J license if any of its owners have an ownership interest, whether direct or
indirect, in any other establishment holding a Class J license within the City.
Violation of this section shall be grounds for revocation of all such liquor
licenses.
      5.   Only Class A, C, or D license holders may apply for and receive a
Class J license, which is held in addition to their other valid Class A, C, or
D license. If the State gaming license is denied or revoked, the Class J
license will not be issued or is automatically revoked, however the licensee
will retain their other valid Class A, C, or D license.
      6.   Video gaming cafes, as defined in section
4-8-6 of this title, are ineligible for a Class J license. (Ord. 1739, 2-12-
2019)
 
Notes
1 1. As defined under the Illinois Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.
4-2-12: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
The City Clerk shall have on file the most recent ordinance setting forth the
current maximum number of each type of license which may be issued in the City.
Notwithstanding the current maximum number of each type of license, upon the
expiration or relinquishment of a license that is not renewed, the maximum
number of available licenses in the class of the expired or relinquished
license shall automatically be reduced by one. (Ord. 1739, 2-12-2019)
4-2-13: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year
after issuance unless sooner revoked as in this chapter provided, and shall not
constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or
execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or
involuntarily, except as provided in subsection A of this section, or subject
to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall not descend by the laws
of testate or intestate devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the
licensee; provided, that executors or administrators of the estate of any
deceased licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when
such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of
the sale of alcoholic liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may
exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after
the death of such decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the
expiration of such license but not longer than six (6) months after the death,
bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. A refund shall be made of that
portion of the license fees paid for any period in which the licensee shall be
prevented from operating under such license in the event of the death or
bankruptcy of the licensee. (1996 Code § 3-32; amd. 2010 Code; Ord. 1738, 1-29-
2019)
   A.   A license may be transferred under certain limited circumstances as
follows:
      1.   The current license holder's business of selling alcoholic beverages
at the current licensed location is under a written contract to be sold, a copy
of which has been provided to the City Clerk along with a completed liquor
license application by the individual(s) or corporate entity owner and
stockholder(s), who are the purchaser(s), and the appropriate license fee(s)
paid, and
      2.   The liquor license application has been approved by the City, and
      3.   The liquor license must remain and is only usable at the same
current licensed location after the sale, and
      4.   The license has not lapsed due to failure to pay the annual license
fee, and
      5.   If the current license holder also holds a Class J license for
operation of video gaming terminals at the same current licensed location, the
purchaser(s) must so indicate on the liquor license application, must pay the
appropriate license fee, and must comply with all Class J license requirements
and State law requirements under the Illinois Video Gaming Act, 230 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq. (Ord. 1738, 1-29-2019)
4-2-14: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   Any licensee may renew the license at the expiration thereof, provided
he is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which such
renewal license is sought is suitable for such purpose; and provided further,
that renewal privilege herein provided for shall be construed as a vested right
which shall, in any case, prevent the City Council from decreasing the number
of licenses to be issued within its jurisdiction. (1996 Code § 3-32)
   B.   Prior to July 1 of each year, license holders shall apply for renewal
of their license. Said renewal shall be on forms provided by the City and shall
include, but not be limited to, a statement, under oath, by the license holder
that no information contained in the original application has changed, or in
the event of a change, the nature and extent of said change. Further, said
renewal application shall contain a statement, under oath, by the license
holder that the license holder and his employees shall have not been arrested
or convicted of any violations of Illinois law or, in the event of said arrest,
the disposition thereof. (1996 Code § 3-38; amd. 2010 Code)
4-2-15: CHANGE OF OWNERSHIP:
Except as provided in subsection 4-2-13A of this chapter, when a current
license holder's business of selling alcoholic beverages at the current
licensed location is being sold under a written contract, this section shall be
applicable to all other changes of ownership. Any change of ownership of the
license holder shall automatically revoke said license. In the case of a
partnership, any change, addition or substitution of a partner shall constitute
a change, thereby revoking said license. In the case of corporations, sale or
transfer of any stock shall constitute a change, thereby revoking said license.
(1996 Code § 3-32; amd. Ord. 1738, 1-29-2019)
4-2-16: RECORDS AND NOTICES:
The Mayor, as Liquor Control Commissioner, shall keep an accurate and up to
date record of all licenses issued pursuant to this chapter and of the fees
collected, and shall furnish the City Clerk, the City Treasurer and the Chief
of Police with a copy thereof. Upon the revocation of any license, the Mayor
shall give written notice thereof to each of the City officers within twenty
four (24) hours after such action. (1996 Code § 3-31)
4-2-17: DAYS AND HOURS OF OPERATION:
   A.   Permitted Hours: Permitted hours for the sale at retail of alcoholic
liquor by establishments licensed under this chapter in the City shall be:
      Sunday, 8:00 A.M. to 1:00 A.M. the following day.
      Monday through Thursday, 6:00 A.M. to 1:00 A.M. the following day.
      Friday and Saturday 6:00 A.M. to 2:00 A.M. the following day.
      Except, the closing hour on New Year's Eve shall be 3:00 A.M. (Ord. 1534,
7-14-2009; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Sales During Permitted Hours Only; Presence On Premises After Hours: It
shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail, give away, or authorize
or allow the consumption of any alcoholic liquor within a licensed
establishment in the City at any time other than during the permitted hours
stated in subsection A of this section. All licensed establishments shall have
ten (10) minutes after the closing hours stated in said subsection A to allow
patrons to vacate the premises each night, including New Year's Eve. Only
owners and employees of the licensed establishment may remain on the premises
after this ten (10) minute period.
   C.   Effect Of Time Changes: No time will be lost or gained in the spring or
fall, respectively, on the dates on which the time changes to and from daylight
saving time. Closing hours on these time change days will be based on the real
time elapsed for the day. (Ord. 1534, 7-14-2009)
4-2-18: EMPLOYEE QUALIFICATIONS:
All persons drawing or serving alcoholic beverages in an establishment in the
City holding a liquor license shall be of the age of twenty one (21) except for
those places or businesses whose primary business is the preparing and serving
of food. In such establishments, a person of the age of eighteen (18) years or
older shall be able to draw or serve alcoholic beverages for those patrons who
are eating at said places of business. (1996 Code § 3-11)
4-2-19: CONDUCT OF BUSINESS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to whom a license has been issued pursuant
to this chapter to permit on the premises for which the license was issued any
loud or unusual noises which disturb the peace and quiet of any neighborhood or
family, or to permit any disorderly or immoral practices, or to permit any
disorderly conduct, open lewdness or any act of public indecency. (1996 Code §
3-10)
4-2-20: SALES TO CERTAIN PERSONS PROHIBITED:
No licensee under this chapter shall sell, give away or deliver, or allow the
same to be done, any alcoholic liquor or malt or vinous beverage to any person
under the age of twenty one (21) years, or to any intoxicated person, except as
provided in 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-16.1. (Ord. 1201, 3-11-1997;
amd. 2010 Code)
4-2-21: PERSONS UNDER TWENTY ONE YEARS ON PREMISES:
   A.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall patronize,
frequent or loiter in any establishment deriving its principal business from
the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises.
   B.   No licensee, under this chapter, or his agent or employee, shall suffer
or permit any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to remain in any
room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to or situated in the room or place
where such licensed premises are located; provided, however, that this
prohibition shall not apply to any person under the age of twenty one (21)
years who is accompanied by his or her parent or guardian, or to any licensed
premises which derives its principal business from the sale of service or of
commodities other than alcoholic liquor.
   C.   Any licensee which provides proof to the Liquor Control Commissioner
that its principal business is derived from the sale of service or commodities,
other than alcoholic liquor, may permit persons under the age of twenty one
(21) years into rooms or compartments adjoining or adjacent to the primary room
or place where such licensee provides the sale of alcoholic liquor, but not
into the primary room provided therefor.
   D.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to a person under the
age of twenty one (21) years who is a lawful employee of a licensed retail
premises under the provisions of this chapter during the time such person under
the age of twenty one (21) years is actually engaged in such employment and to
the extent necessary in connection therewith. (Ord. 1201, 3-11-1997; amd. 2010
Code)
4-2-22: LEWD ENTERTAINMENT PROHIBITED:
No person licensed under this chapter shall permit any employee, entertainer or
patron to engage in any live act, demonstration, dance, or exhibition on the
licensed premises which:
   A.   Exposes his or her genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, perineum, anal
region or pubic hair region; or
   B.   Exposes any device, costume or covering which gives the appearance of
or simulates the genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, perineum, anal region or pubic
hair region; or
   C.   Exposes any portion of the female breast at or below the areola
thereof. (1996 Code § 3-36)
4-2-23: TRANSPORTING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES:
   A.   Except as provided in subsection C of this section, no driver may
transport, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor within the passenger
area of any motor vehicle upon a highway in the City except in the original
container and with the seal unbroken.
   B.   Except as provided in subsection C of this section and 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/6-33, no passenger may carry, possess or have any alcoholic
liquor within any passenger area of any motor vehicle upon a roadway in the
City except in the original container and with the seal unbroken.
   C.   This section shall not apply to the passengers in a limousine when it
is being used for purposes for which a limousine is ordinarily used, the
passengers on a chartered bus when it is being used for purposes for which
chartered buses are ordinarily used or on a "motor home" or "mini-motor home"
as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-145.01. However, the driver of
any such vehicle is prohibited from consuming or having any alcoholic liquor in
or about the driver's area. Any evidence of alcohol consumption by the driver
shall be prima facie evidence of such driver's failure to obey this section.
For the purposes of this section, a "limousine" is a motor vehicle of the first
division with the passenger compartment enclosed by a partition or dividing
window used in the for-hire transportation of passengers and operated by an
individual in possession of a valid Illinois driver's license of the
appropriate classification pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-104.
(1996 Code § 3-4; amd. 2010 Code)
4-2-24: ADDITIONAL RESTRICTED AND PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Curb Service: It shall be unlawful to serve or permit alcoholic liquor
to be served in automobiles or any other vehicle in or upon the premises, or
upon the streets, highways, sidewalks or alleys adjacent or adjoining the
premises described in any license issued pursuant to this chapter, which manner
of serving is commonly known as "curb service". However, this shall not apply
to package liquor sales not intended for consumption inside the automobile.
(1996 Code § 3-5)
   B.   Possession By Class A Licensee: It shall be unlawful for any person
holding a Class A license issued pursuant to this chapter to keep, store or
have in his possession on the premises for which the license is issued any
alcoholic beverage other than beer and wine. (1996 Code § 3-7)
   C.   Consumption On Class A And B Premises: It shall be unlawful for any
person holding a Class A or a Class B license issued pursuant to this chapter
to permit the mixing or drinking of alcoholic drinks upon the premises for
which the license is issued, except beer and wine in the case of a Class A
license holder. (1996 Code § 3-8)
   D.   Drinking Alcoholic Beverages Outside Public Places Or Upon Public Ways:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the City limits to drink any beer,
wine, or other alcoholic liquor outside of a public place or upon the streets
or sidewalks. (1996 Code § 3-12; amd. 2010 Code)
4-2-25: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
   A.   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner may revoke or suspend any license
issued by him if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the
provisions of the Liquor Control Act, this chapter, or any applicable rule or
regulation established by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner or the State
Liquor Control Commission which is not inconsistent with law. In addition to
the suspension, the Local Liquor Control Commissioner may levy a fine on the
licensee for such violations. The fine imposed shall not exceed one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for a first violation within a twelve (12) month period,
one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation within a
twelve (12) month period, and two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for
a third or subsequent violation within a twelve (12) month period. Each day on
which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. Not more
than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) in fines under this section may be
imposed against any licensee during the period of his license. Proceeds from
such fines shall be paid into the General Corporate Fund of the City Treasury.
   B.   However, no such license shall be so revoked or suspended and no
licensee shall be fined except after a public hearing by the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner with a three (3) day written notice to the licensee
affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend. All such hearings
shall be open to the public, and the Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall
electronically record all proceedings and reduce all transcripts to writing if
requested, and shall maintain an official record of the proceedings. If the
Local Liquor Control Commissioner has reason to believe that any continued
operation of a particular licensed premises will immediately threaten the
welfare of the community, he may, upon the issuance of a written order stating
the reason for such conclusion and without notice or hearing, order the
licensed premises closed for not more than seven (7) days, giving the licensee
an opportunity to be heard during that period; except, that if such licensee
shall also be engaged in the conduct of another business or businesses on the
licensed premises, such order shall not be applicable to such other business or
businesses.
   C.   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall, within five (5) days after
such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be
revoked or suspended or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason or
reasons for such determination in a written order, and either the amount of the
fine, the period of suspension, or that the license has been revoked, and shall
serve a copy of such order within the five (5) days upon the licensee. (1996
Code § 3-35; amd. 2010 Code)
CHAPTER 3
AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS; COIN OPERATED DEVICES
SECTION:
4-3-1: Application Of Provisions
4-3-2: Amusements And Entertainments
4-3-3: Coin Operated Amusement Devices; Play For Pay Games
4-3-4: Coin Operated Music Devices
4-3-5: Cigarette Machines
4-3-6: Revocation Of License
4-3-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
Each license granted under the provisions of this chapter and each licensee
herein shall be subject to the provisions of this code. (1996 Code § 4-2; amd.
2010 Code)
4-3-2: AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS:
   A.   License Fees: The fees for the various classes of entertainment
licenses required by this section shall be as established from time to time by
the city council by resolution or ordinance. (1996 Code § 4-1)
   B.   Good Order; Presence Of Police: Each person giving or conducting any
exhibition, show or amusement shall preserve good order in and about the place
of the exhibition, show or amusement and, if necessary for that purpose, shall
employ, at his own expense, sufficient security personnel to maintain good
order. (1996 Code § 4-4; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Admission Of Police Officers To Premises: Any regular police officer of
the city, while on duty, shall be entitled, without charge or hindrance, to
enter any place of business where any entertainment is being given or is to be
given for the purpose of preserving order therein and enforcing the provisions
of this code and other ordinances of the city, and no owner, manager or lessee
of any place of business or his agent shall prohibit or attempt to prohibit or
interfere with or attempt to interfere with any such police officer. (1996 Code
§ 4-3)
4-3-3: COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES; PLAY FOR PAY GAMES:
   A.   License Required: No person shall allow the public to use any coin
operated amusement device or play for pay device in any public or private place
without first obtaining a license for each such machine, as provided in this
section. (1996 Code § 4-21)
   B.   Application For License: The application for and issuance of a license
required by this section shall be made as provided by the provisions of this
title regulating licenses 1 . The application shall give the name of the
applicant, a description of the machine, including the factory, model or other
distinguishing number or identification, and the denomination of the coins
required for its operation or the value of the token used in lieu thereof.
(1996 Code § 4-22)
   C.   License Fees:
      1.   The annual fee for a license required by this section shall be
twenty five dollars ($25.00).
      2.   The weekly fee for a license required by this section shall be five
dollars ($5.00) per machine. (1996 Code § 4-23)
   D.   Expiration Of License: Each annual license issued pursuant to this
section shall expire on December 31 next following its issuance, and each
weekly license shall expire on the seventh day of its issuance. (1996 Code § 4-
24)
   E.   Display Of License: A license issued pursuant to this section shall be
affixed in a conspicuous place in or upon the machine for which it is issued.
(1996 Code § 4-25)
   F.   Billiard And Pool Halls; Days And Hours Of Operation: Any license under
subsection A of this section, whose primary business is billiards or pool
tables, may be open to business during the hours set forth in section
4-2-17 of this title. (Ord. 1202, 3-25-1997)
   G.   Presence Of Intoxicated Persons Prohibited: No licensee under
subsection A of this section, whose primary business is billiards or pool
tables or any coin operated amusement device or play for pay games, shall allow
any intoxicated individual to frequent or loiter about or remain in the
premises or to play at any game or roll any ball upon any such table therein.
(1996 Code § 4-53)

   B.   Application For License: The application for a license required by this

required for its operation or the value of the token used in lieu thereof.
(1996 Code § 4-28)

shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). (1996 Code § 4-29)
   D.   Expiration Of License: Each license issued pursuant to this section
shall expire on December 31 next following its issuance. (1996 Code § 4-30)
   E.   Display Of License: A license issued pursuant to this section shall be
affixed in a conspicuous place in or upon the machine for which it is issued.
(1996 Code § 4-31)

4-3-5: CIGARETTE MACHINES:

   D.   Expiration Of License: Each license issued pursuant to this section
shall expire on December 31 next following its issuance. (1996 Code § 4-36)
   E.   Display Of License: A license issued pursuant to this section shall be
affixed in a conspicuous place in or upon the machine for which it is issued.
(1996 Code § 4-37)

4-3-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Whenever, in the judgment of the city council, any section of this chapter or
any of the conditions in the application for license for any machine described
herein has been or is being violated, the council may, in its discretion,
revoke the license of any or all machines on the premises. (1996 Code § 4-72)
CHAPTER 4
PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND TRANSIENT VENDORS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Exemptions From Provisions
4-4-2: Violation; Penalty
4-4-1: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The following shall be exempt from the application and license requirements of
this chapter:
   A.   Nonprofit Organizations: Any person selling or taking orders for any
goods or services not prohibited by law on behalf of a nonprofit organization,
educational institution located in Jersey County, or fraternal organization
sponsored by or participated in by a local chapter of such organization.
   B.   Celebrations: Any person selling or taking orders for goods or services
not prohibited by law while participating in any fair, festival, parade or
other celebration conducted by organizations, educational institutions or
committees located in Jersey County and approved by the city council.
   C.   Garage Or Yard Sales: Any sale of merchandise, goods or wares conducted
at any residence in the city, not located in the business district, commonly
referred to as a garage or yard sale, provided such sale shall be conducted for
a period not to exceed three (3) consecutive days.
   D.   Persons Under Age Of Twelve: Sales by any person under the age of
twelve (12) years. (1996 Code § 16-102)
   E.   Jersey County Residents: Jersey County residents selling home grown
products from a stand. (Ord. 1183, 6-4-1996)
4-4-2: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the terms of this chapter shall be guilty of a
petty offense and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each
day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. (1996 Code §§ 16-103, 16-
128; amd. 2010 Code)
ARTICLE A. PEDDLERS AND HAWKERS
SECTION:
4-4A-1: Definition
4-4A-2: License Required; Exception
4-4A-3: Application For And Issuance Of License
4-4A-4: License Fee
4-4A-5: Expiration Of License
4-4A-1: DEFINITION:
Whoever shall peddle or sell or attempt to peddle or sell, or hawk or attempt
to hawk goods, wares, merchandise or other articles from door to door and place
to place in the city shall be, for this article, a "hawker" or "peddler". (1996
Code § 16-66; amd. 2010 Code)
4-4A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a hawker or
peddler in the city without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in
this article. No license otherwise required by this section shall be required
of any person to sell vegetables or other produce of his own farm or garden.
(1996 Code § 16-74)
4-4A-3: APPLICATION FOR AND ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The application for and the issuance of a license required by this article
shall be as established in chapter 1 of this title. (1996 Code § 16-75)
4-4A-4: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   Established By Ordinance Or Resolution: The fee for a license required
by this article shall be as established from time to time by the city council
by ordinance or resolution. (1996 Code § 16-76)
   B.   Exemption From Fee: Whenever, in the judgment of the mayor, it would be
proper to allow any person in need to sell or peddle notions or other like
property without requiring the license fee otherwise established pursuant to
subsection A of this section to be paid, the mayor may grant such person a
permit to sell free of charge, which permit may be revoked at any time in the
discretion of the mayor. (1996 Code § 16-76; amd. 2010 Code)
4-4A-5: EXPIRATION OF LICENSE:
A license issued pursuant to this article shall expire at the end of the fiscal
year of the city during which it was issued. (1996 Code § 16-77)
CHAPTER 4
PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS
ARTICLE B. ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND TRANSIENT VENDORS
SECTION:
4-4B-1: Definition
4-4B-2: License Required; Conditions
4-4B-3: Application For And Issuance Of License
4-4B-4: License Fees
4-4B-5: Term Of License
4-4B-6: Posting Of License
4-4B-7: Record Of Licenses
4-4B-1: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this article, any person, whether or not the person is an
employee of another person, who, on real property in which he does not hold a
fee simple interest, or does not have a leasehold interest of at least six (6)
months, establishes a display, exhibition, or sales facility for the purpose of
selling, offering, or displaying for sale and immediate delivery of tangible
personal property at retail, or sale of food shall be considered an "itinerant
merchant" or "transient vendor" for purposes of this article, if: (1996 Code §
16-89; amd. 2010 Code)
   A.   The display, exhibition, or sales facility is established with the
intent that such display, exhibition, or sales facility will remain in
operation for a period of less than six (6) months; or
   B.   The display, exhibition, or sales facility is established with the
intent that its operation will be interrupted for a period of more than ninety
(90) days in any calendar year; or
   C.   The display, exhibition, or sales facility is established in a
temporary structure, including, but not limited to, travel trailers, mobile
homes, or tents. (1996 Code § 16-89)
4-4B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; CONDITIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, whether as principal, agent, attorney,
clerk, servant, employee or officer of a corporation, to engage in, carry on,
or assist in carrying on the business, occupation, or calling of an itinerant
merchant or transient vendor of any merchandise, wares, goods, or prepared food
within the city without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this
article. No itinerant merchant or transient vendor shall be allowed to evade
the provisions of this article by employing an auctioneer to sell his goods.
(1996 Code § 16-96; amd. 2010 Code)
4-4B-3: APPLICATION FOR AND ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
Application for a license required by this article and the issuance thereof
shall be in the manner prescribed in chapter 1 of this title. (1996 Code § 16-
97)
4-4B-4: LICENSE FEES:
The license fees for selling all classes of goods, wares, and merchandise and
prepared food shall be four hundred dollars ($400.00) per month or twenty five
dollars ($25.00) per day. (1996 Code § 16-98)
4-4B-5: TERM OF LICENSE:
No license shall be issued pursuant to this article for a period of time less
than one month. (1996 Code § 16-99)
4-4B-6: POSTING OF LICENSE:
A person to whom a license is issued pursuant to this article shall keep the
license posted in a conspicuous place in his place of business. (1996 Code §
16-100)
4-4B-7: RECORD OF LICENSES:
The city clerk shall keep a record of all licenses granted under this article,
in which shall be recorded the name of the person licensed, the time of issuing
the license and the place of business of the person so licensed. (1996 Code §
16-101)
ARTICLE C. SOLICITORS
SECTION:
4-4C-1: Definition
4-4C-2: License And Certificate Of Registration Required
4-4C-3: Persons Ineligible For Certificate
4-4C-4: Applications For License And Certificate
4-4C-5: License Fee
4-4C-6: Issuance Or Denial Of Certificate
4-4C-7: Contents Of Certificate
4-4C-8: Time Limit On Soliciting
4-4C-9: Revocation Of Certificate
4-4C-10: Exemptions From Provisions
4-4C-1: DEFINITION:
Any person who shall go in and upon private residences, business establishments
or offices in the city for the purpose of soliciting orders for the purchase of
any merchandise or commodity, or for the purpose of accepting contributions for
any purpose or for the purpose of distribution of informational literature
which may eventually lead to a sale of any merchandise or commodity shall be
deemed a "solicitor" within the meaning of this article. (1996 Code § 16-114;
amd. 2010 Code)
4-4C-2: LICENSE AND CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business in the city as a
solicitor without first obtaining a license and certificate of registration
therefor as prescribed in this article. (1996 Code § 16-124)
4-4C-3: PERSONS INELIGIBLE FOR CERTIFICATE:
No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been
convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois
or any other state or federal law of the United States within five (5) years of
the date of the application; nor to any person who has been convicted of a
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter; nor to any person whose
certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously been revoked as
herein provided. (1996 Code § 16-125)
4-4C-4: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSE AND CERTIFICATE:
   A.   License: Any person who desires a license as a solicitor, required by
this article, shall make application in writing therefor to the mayor, setting
out in the application the full name and residence of the applicant and the
company by whom he is employed as a solicitor. The application shall also state
what commodity or article of merchandise such solicitor desires or intends to
sell, or for what purpose contributions are being sought. (1996 Code § 16-125;
amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Certificate Of Registration: Application for a certificate of
registration shall be made upon a form provided by the chief of police of the
city and filed with such chief. The application shall truthfully state in full
the information requested on the application, as follows:
      1.   Name and address of present place of residence and length of
residence at such address; also business address if other than residence
address; also social security number.
      2.   Address of place of residence during the past three (3) years if
other than present address.
      3.   Age of applicant and marital status; and if married, the name of the
applicant's spouse.
      4.   Physical description of applicant.
      5.   Name and address of the person, firm or corporation or association
whom the applicant is employed by or represents; and the length of time of such
employment or representation.
      6.   Name and address of employer during the past three (3) years if
other than the present employer.
      7.   Description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of
the soliciting in which the applicant will engage.
      8.   Period of time for which the certificate is applied.
      9.   The date or approximate date of the latest previous application for
certificate under this article, if any.
      10.   Has a certificate of registration issued to the applicant under
this article ever been revoked?
      11.   Has the applicant ever been convicted of a violation of any of the
provisions of this article or an ordinance of any other Illinois municipality
regulating soliciting?
      12.   Has the applicant ever been convicted of the commission of a felony
under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state or federal laws of
the United States?
      13.   Also, such additional information as the chief of police may deem
necessary to process the application.
   C.   Records Of Applications: The chief of police shall cause to be kept in
his office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon,
together with all other information and data pertaining thereto and all
certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this article, and
of the denial of applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered
in consecutive order as filed, and every certificate issued and any renewal
thereof shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon
which it was issued. (1996 Code § 16-125)
4-4C-5: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for a license required by this article shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00) per day, per person, in advance. (1996 Code § 16-126; amd. 2010 Code)
4-4C-6: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF CERTIFICATE:
The chief of police, after consideration of the application and all information
obtained relative hereto, shall deny the application if the applicant does not
possess the qualifications for such certificate as herein required or if the
issuance of a certificate of registration to the applicant would not be in
accord with the intent and purpose of this article. Endorsement shall be made
by the chief of police upon the application of the denial of the application.
When the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the certificate of
registration shall be issued forthwith. (1996 Code § 16-127)
4-4C-7: CONTENTS OF CERTIFICATE:
The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date thereof. (1996
Code § 16-127)
4-4C-8: TIME LIMIT ON SOLICITING:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any
person to solicit as defined in this article C, whether registered under this
article C or not, on Saturdays, Sundays, and state and national holidays. It
shall be lawful to solicit on weekdays Monday through Friday from nine o’clock
(9:00) A.M. to five o’clock (5:00) P.M. each day, except on state and national
holidays. (Ord. 1812, 6-11-2024)
4-4C-9: REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE:
Any certificate of registration issued under this article shall be revoked by
the chief of police if the holder of the certificate is convicted of violating
any of the provisions of this article, or has made a false material statement
in the application, or has otherwise become disqualified for the issuance of a
certificate of registration under the terms of this article. Immediately upon
such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police
to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed
to his or her residence as set forth by the application. Immediately upon the
giving of such notice, the certificate of registration shall become null and
void. (1996 Code § 16-127)
4-4C-10: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS 1 :
The provisions of this article shall not apply to persons represented by or
representing any established merchant, business or corporation located and
regularly doing business in the city, nor to farmers selling food items raised
or produced by themselves, nor to permanently established residents who are
voters in the city, to anyone duly licensed or to anyone who seeks and obtains,
at a regularly held city council meeting, the permission of the city council to
be excepted from the provisions of this article. (1996 Code § 16-115; amd. 2010
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 4-4-1 of this chapter.
CHAPTER 5
PAWNBROKERS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Definition
4-5-2: License Required
4-5-3: Persons Ineligible For License
4-5-4: Application For License
4-5-5: License Fee
4-5-6: Bond Requirements
4-5-7: Issuance Or Denial Of License
4-5-8: Records Of Property
4-5-9: Memorandum To Pledgor
4-5-10: Prohibited Transactions
4-5-11: Minors
4-5-12: Hours Of Operation
4-5-13: Revocation Of License
4-5-14: Penalty
4-5-1: DEFINITION:
Every individual or business entity which lends money on the deposit or pledge
of physically delivered personal property, other than property the ownership of
which is subject to a legal dispute, securities, printed evidence of
indebtedness or printed evidence of ownership of the personal property, or who
deals in the purchase of such property on the condition of selling the property
back again at a stipulated price, shall be held and is hereby declared and
defined to be a "pawnbroker". The business of a "pawnbroker" does not include
the lending of money on deposit or pledge of title to property. (Ord. 1276, 11-
2-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
4-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person or business entity to engage in, carry on,
manage, operate or conduct the business of a pawnbroker within the city without
first having obtained a pawnbroker license to so operate. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-
1999; amd. 2010 Code)
4-5-3: PERSONS INELIGIBLE FOR LICENSE:
No license shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of any felony
or any misdemeanor pertaining to theft or the possession of stolen property;
nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter; nor to any person whose license issued hereunder
has previously been revoked as herein provided. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999; amd.
2010 Code)
4-5-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Any person who desires a license required by this chapter as a
pawnbroker shall make application in writing therefor to the mayor, setting out
in the application the full name and residence of the applicant and the company
by whom he is employed.
   B.   Application for a license shall be made upon a form provided by the
chief of police of the city and filed with such chief. The application shall
truthfully state, in full, the information requested on the application, as
follows: (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999)
      1.   Names and addresses of present places of residence and length of
residence at such addresses of all owners, partners, managers, or officers or
shareholders of a corporation; also, business addresses if other than residence
addresses; also, social security numbers. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999; amd. 2010
Code)
      2.   Address of place of residence during the past three (3) years if
other than present address.
      3.   Age of applicant and marital status; and if married, the name of
applicant's spouse.
      4.   Physical description of applicant.
      5.   Name and address of employer during the past three (3) years.
      6.   The date or approximate date of the latest previous pawnshop
operated by the applicant.
      7.   Has the applicant ever been convicted of the commission of any
crime?
      8.   Also, such additional information as the chief of police may deem
necessary to process the application.
   C.   The chief of police shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate
record of every application received and acted upon, together with all other
information and data pertaining thereto, and of the denial of applications.
(Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999)
4-5-5: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for a license required by this chapter shall be five hundred dollars
($500.00) per year, in advance. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999)
4-5-6: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Every person so licensed shall, at the time of receiving such license, execute
a bond to the city in the sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) with at least
two (2) good and sufficient sureties, conditioned for the due observance of the
provisions of this code, respecting pawnbrokers, at any time during the
continuance of such license. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
4-5-7: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
The mayor, after investigation of the application and all information obtained
relative thereto by the chief of police, shall deny the application if the
applicant does not possess the qualifications for such license as herein
required or if the issuance of a certificate of license to the applicant would
not be in accord with the intent and purpose of this chapter. Endorsement shall
be made by the chief of police upon the application of the denial of the
application. When the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the license
shall be issued forthwith. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999)
4-5-8: RECORDS OF PROPERTY:
   A.   Records Required; Contents: Every pawnbroker shall keep a book in which
shall be printed, typed or written in ink, at the time of each and every loan
or taking of a pledge, an accurate account and description, in the English
language, of all the goods, articles and other things pawned or pledged, the
amount of money, value or thing loaned thereon, the time of pledging the same,
the rate of interest to be paid on such loan, and the name and residence of the
person making such pawn or pledge. Such entry shall include the serial number
or identification number of items received which bear such number. Except for
items purchased from dealers possessing a federal employee identification
number who have provided a receipt to the pawnbroker, every pawnbroker shall
also record in his book, an accurate account and description, in the English
language, of all goods, articles and other things purchased or received for the
purpose of resale or loan collateral by the pawnbroker from any source, not in
the course of a pledge or loan, the time of such purchase or receipt and the
name and address of the person or business which sold or delivered such goods,
articles, or other things to the pawnbroker. No entry in such book shall be
erased, mutilated or changed.
   B.   Open To Inspection; Time For Retention: The said book, as well as every
article or other thing of value so pawned or pledged, shall at all times be
open to the inspection of the mayor or any members of the police force of the
city and shall be kept three (3) years after the date on which the record was
prepared. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Daily Copy Of Records: It shall be the duty of every person licensed as
aforesaid to make out and deliver to the chief of police of the city, on each
day before the hour of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon, a legible and correct copy
from said book, as required in subsection A of this section, of all personal
property and other valuable things received on deposit or purchased during the
preceding day, together with the exact time when received or purchased, and a
description of the person or persons by whom left in pledge, or from whom the
same were purchased. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999)
4-5-9: MEMORANDUM TO PLEDGOR:
Every pawnbroker shall, at the time of each loan, deliver to the person pawning
or pledging any goods, articles or things, a memorandum, contract or note
signed by him, containing the substance of the entry required to be made in his
book by subsection 4-5-8A of this chapter, and no charge shall be made or
received by any pawnbroker for any such entry, memorandum, contract or note.
(Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
4-5-10: PROHIBITED TRANSACTIONS:
   A.   Property Of Intoxicated Person Or Thief: No pawnbroker shall take any
article in pawn or pledge from any person appearing to be intoxicated, nor from
any person known to have been convicted of theft; and when any person is found
to be the owner of stolen property which has been pawned, such property shall
be returned to the owner thereof, without the payment of the money advanced by
the pawnbroker thereon, or any costs or charges of any kind, which the
pawnbroker may have placed upon the same.
   B.   Purchases By Pawnbroker: No pawnbroker shall, under any pretense
whatever, purchase or buy any secondhand furniture, metals or clothes or any
other article or thing whatever offered to him as a pawn or pledge.
   C.   Sale Of Property: No personal property received on deposit or pledge or
purchased by any pawnbroker shall be sold or permitted to be redeemed or
removed from the place of business of such pawnbroker for the space of forty
eight (48) hours after the delivery of the copy and statement required by
subsection 4-5-8C of this chapter required to be delivered to the chief of
police. If the pawner or pledger fails to repay the loan during the period
specified on the pawn ticket, the pawnbroker shall automatically extend a grace
period of thirty (30) days from the default date on the loan during which the
pawnbroker shall not dispose of or sell the personal property pledged. The
parties may agree to extend or renew a loan upon terms agreed upon by the
parties, provided the terms comply with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord.
1276, 11-2-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
4-5-11: MINORS:
   A.   Pledge From Minor: No pawnbroker shall take or receive any pawn or
pledge for any advancement or loan, any property of any kind from any minor who
is under eighteen (18) years of age, or the ownership of which is in, or which
is claimed by, any such minor, or which may be in the possession or under the
control of any such minor. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Employment: No person licensed under this chapter shall permit any
person under the age of eighteen (18) years to take pledges in pawn for him.
(Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999)
4-5-12: HOURS OF OPERATION:
No person licensed under this chapter shall receive or deposit or pledge any
personal property or other valuable thing before the hour of six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. or after the hour of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. during the months of
January, February, March, April, October, November and December of each year;
nor before the hour of five o'clock (5:00) A.M. or after the hour of ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. during the months of May, June, July, August and September
of each year. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999)
4-5-13: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued hereunder shall be revoked by the mayor if the holder of the
license is convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter, or has
made a false material statement in the application, or has otherwise become
disqualified for the issuance of a license under the terms of this chapter.
Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the
chief of police to the holder of the license in person or by certified U.S.
mail addressed to his or her residence as set forth by the application.
Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the license shall become null and
void. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999)
4-5-14: PENALTY:
Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or
who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation is
permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 1276, 11-2-1999;
amd. 2010 Code)
CHAPTER 6
TAXICABS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Definitions
4-6-2: Owner Licensing Provisions
4-6-3: Driver Licensing Provisions
4-6-4: Record Of Licenses
4-6-5: Vehicles To Be Identified
4-6-6: Rates Of Fare
4-6-7: Operation Of Taxicab
4-6-8: Suspension Or Revocation Of Licenses
4-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed
to them in this section:
DRIVER: Means and includes every person in charge of or operating any taxicab,
either as an agent, employee or otherwise.
OWNER: Any person who has the bona fide legal title or the control, direction,
operation, maintenance, leasing or collection of revenues derived from taxicabs
operated for hire on the streets in the city.
TAXICAB: All motor vehicles propelled and operated for passenger hire subject
to call from a stand, station or garage or otherwise operating for hire, except
motor buses running and operating on established routes, sightseeing buses and
funeral vehicles. (1996 Code § 29-16)
4-6-2: OWNER LICENSING PROVISIONS:
   A.   License Required: No person shall own any taxicab without first
obtaining a taxicab license therefor as provided in this section. (1996 Code §
29-47)
   B.   Application For License: Any person desiring a license required by this
section shall file an application therefor with the city clerk upon a form
provided for that purpose, setting forth the name, business and residence
address of the applicant; a full description of the motor vehicle for which the
license is desired, including the make, model, vehicle number and number of
passengers that may be accommodated in the motor vehicle; the place where the
motor vehicle is to be kept when not in use; the number and kinds of other
motor vehicles owned by the applicant; the state license number of the motor
vehicle; the persons engaged to drive the motor vehicle; and any other
information as the mayor or the city clerk may from time to time require. (1996
Code § 29-49)
   C.   Insurance Requirements: The applicant for a license required by this
section shall file with the city clerk a contract or policy of insurance,
issued to the applicant for the full period to be covered by the license, upon
the motor vehicle for which the license is applied. The contract or policy of
insurance shall meet the requirements of state law for financial
responsibility. The mayor may refer any contract or policy of insurance filed
pursuant to this subsection to the city attorney for recommendation as to
approval and as to whether or not the policy conforms to the requirements of
the state. (1996 Code § 29-50)
   D.   License Fee: The applicant for a license required by this section shall
pay to the city clerk an annual license fee of ten dollars ($10.00). In the
event the license is not issued, the fee shall be refunded by the city clerk to
the applicant. (1996 Code § 29-51)
   E.   Issuance Of License: In the event the applicant for a license required
by this section fully complies with the requirements of this section and pays
the license fee specified in this section for the taxicab, the mayor shall
issue or cause to be issued the license sought, which license shall be attested
by the city clerk and shall authorize the use of such taxicab for the
transportation of persons for hire upon the streets and public thoroughfares of
the city. (1996 Code § 29-52)
   F.   Expiration Of License: A license issued pursuant to this section shall
expire on December 31 next following its issuance. (1996 Code § 29-53)
   G.   Display Of License Sticker: Each taxicab which may be licensed pursuant
to this section and operated in the city shall exhibit a sticker, which shall
be provided by the city clerk, which shall not be less than four inches (4") in
diameter, and said sticker shall indicate that a license has been issued for
the taxicab to the owner or operator thereof and which sticker shall be placed
on the windshield of the taxicab operated under the license. (1996 Code § 29-
54)
   H.   Number Of Licenses; Revocation: There shall not be more than three (3)
taxicab owners' licenses issued in the city for any one year. Such three (3)
licenses may be owned by the same person, in which case, they shall be subject
to revocation if such person ceases to furnish taxicab service or fails to give
adequate and satisfactory service to the public. (1996 Code § 29-48)
4-6-3: DRIVER LICENSING PROVISIONS:
   A.   License Required; Scope: It shall be unlawful for any person to drive,
operate or be in charge of any taxicab in the city without first obtaining a
license therefor in writing from the mayor. Each license issued pursuant to
this section shall entitle the holder thereof to drive a taxicab licensed
pursuant to this chapter for the current license year, upon the payment of the
license fee. (1996 Code §§ 29-32, 29-40)
   B.   Persons Ineligible For License: No license required by this section
shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the violation of any
felony or law against reckless driving; or who is less than eighteen (18) years
of age; or who is not physically or morally a person who should be permitted to
operate a taxicab; or where the safety of the public might be endangered by the
granting of the license. (1996 Code § 29-38; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Application For License:
      1.   Contents Of Application: A person desiring a license required by
this section shall file with the mayor an application in writing upon forms
furnished by the city clerk. The application shall state the experience of the
applicant in driving motor vehicles; the physical condition, including the
eyesight and hearing, of the applicant; whether such person has ever been
convicted for violation of any motor vehicle or traffic ordinance or law or
felony, whether city, county, state or federal, and the number of times, if
any, and the various offenses charged. (1996 Code § 29-33; amd. 2010 Code)
      2.   Physician's Statement: In case an application filed pursuant to this
section is for an original license and not the renewal of a license previously
issued, the application shall be accompanied by the signed statement of a
practicing physician that the applicant is physically fit to operate a taxicab
and has no uncorrected defects in eyesight and no impairment of hearing. (1996
Code § 29-34)
      3.   Photographs:
         a.   Each applicant for a license required by this section shall file
with his application two (2) recent photographs of himself, of a size which may
be easily attached to his license, one of which shall be attached to the
license when issued and the other of which shall be kept with the application.
The photograph shall be so attached to the license that it cannot be removed
and another photograph substituted without detection. (1996 Code § 29-35)
         b.   In the event the application for a license required by this
section is denied, the photographs submitted pursuant to subsection C3a of this
section shall be returned to the applicant. (1996 Code § 29-35; amd. 2010 Code)
   D.   License Fee: The annual fee for each original license required by this
section, or the renewal thereof, shall be ten dollars ($10.00). (1996 Code §
29-36; amd. 2010 Code)
   E.   Investigation Of Applicant: The mayor shall investigate, or cause to be
investigated, the facts stated in the application for a license required by
this section, before issuing the license. (1996 Code § 29-37)
   F.   Issuance Of License: The mayor, upon finding the applicant for a
license required by this section to be eligible for the license, shall issue a
metal badge of such design and bearing such words and numerals as may be
prescribed by the mayor, with the driver's license number thereon; and shall
also issue a cardboard license for the current license year of such size and
design as may be prescribed by the mayor, containing the name of the driver and
with his photograph fastened thereon as prescribed in this section. (1996 Code
§ 29-39)
   G.   Presentation Of License: Each driver licensed pursuant to this section
shall, upon demand of an inspector of licenses, a police officer or a
passenger, exhibit his license and photograph for inspection. (1996 Code § 29-
41)
4-6-4: RECORD OF LICENSES:
There shall be kept in the office of the city clerk a complete record of each
taxicab license and of each license issued to a driver pursuant to this
chapter, and of all renewals, suspensions and revocations thereof, which record
shall be kept on file with the original applications for licenses. (1996 Code §
29-17)
4-6-5: VEHICLES TO BE IDENTIFIED:
Each taxicab licensed pursuant to this chapter shall have painted, printed or
attached thereto in the center of one of the door panels on each side of the
taxicab, in letters at least two inches (2") in height, the name of the company
or individual operating the taxicab. There shall also be painted or printed on
the front and back of the taxicab a numeral indicating the number of the
taxicab, if more than one cab is operated by any person, which numeral shall be
at least six inches (6") in height. (1996 Code § 29-18)
4-6-6: RATES OF FARE:
The maximum rates which may be charged by an owner licensed pursuant to this
chapter shall be as established from time to time by the city council by
ordinance or resolution. (1996 Code § 29-19)
4-6-7: OPERATION OF TAXICAB:
   A.   Drivers Remain In Taxicab; Exceptions: The driver of a taxicab subject
to this chapter shall remain upon the driver's seat or inside his taxicab at
all times while the taxicab is standing upon a public stand; however, nothing
in this subsection shall prohibit a driver from leaving the taxicab for such
times as may be necessary to assist passengers into or out of his taxicab, nor
from leaving the taxicab for such a length of time as may be necessary for him
to use the telephone in connection with the operation of the taxicab. Loitering
or standing upon the sidewalks or in the lobbies or entrances of buildings or
stores by taxicab drivers shall be unlawful. (1996 Code § 29-20)
   B.   Prepayment Of Fare: Every driver of a taxicab shall have the right to
demand the payment of the regular fare in advance and may refuse employment
unless so prepaid; but no driver of a taxicab shall refuse or neglect, upon
request, to convey any orderly person so tendering the fare in advance to any
place in the city, unless the driver is previously engaged. (1996 Code § 29-21)
   C.   Carrying Other Than Original Passenger: No driver of a taxicab subject
to this chapter shall carry any person other than the passenger by whom he has
been engaged without the consent of the passenger. (1996 Code § 29-22)
   D.   Maximum Number Of Passengers: No more than five (5) persons, in
addition to the driver of any taxicab subject to this chapter, shall be carried
at any one time. (1996 Code § 29-23)
   E.   Soliciting Business Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person in
the taxicab business, his employees, servants or agents, to travel or operate
over or upon the streets of the city in the act of solicitation of passengers
for hire. (1996 Code § 29-24)
   F.   Operation From Taxicab Stands: An owner or his employees, servants or
agents shall render service on demand from taxicab stands, the location and
places thereof to be designated or approved by the mayor. (1996 Code § 29-25)
4-6-8: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
The mayor and the city council shall have the authority to revoke or suspend
the license of any taxicab owner whose vehicle is not found safe or in good
condition, and the mayor may revoke any license issued under the provisions of
this chapter for failure on the part of any owner, operator, driver, lessee or
licensee to comply with all of the provisions of this chapter, or for failure
to comply with any state law pertaining to the operation of a motor vehicle, or
for failure to comply with any provision of this chapter or other city
ordinance or traffic regulation. In the event of the suspension or revocation
of a license, no refund shall be made to the person to whom the license was
issued for any portion of the license fee previously paid. (1996 Code § 29-26)
CHAPTER 7
PROCESSING WILD GAME
SECTION:
4-7-1: State License Required
4-7-2: Entry Powers Of Enforcement Officials
4-7-3: Suspension Of Operation
4-7-4: Severability
4-7-5: Penalty
4-7-1: STATE LICENSE REQUIRED:
Any individual, corporation, partnership or any other entity within the
corporate limits of the city that engages in the business of cutting up or
preparing in any way for human consumption wild game carcasses including, but
not limited to, deer, whether for sale or for the benefit of a third party,
shall have a type I license as defined in 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 654/
5.1. (Ord. 1379, 9-27-2002)
4-7-2: ENTRY POWERS OF ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS:
No person shall deny access to any authorized personnel of the city upon
presentation of proper identification at any reasonable time to any part of the
establishment for the purpose of making a determination whether said license is
in place and whether there is compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 1379, 9-27-
2002)
4-7-3: SUSPENSION OF OPERATION:
The code enforcement officer of the city is hereby authorized to suspend the
operation of any entity found to be processing wild game carcasses without the
license herein required. (Ord. 1379, 9-27-2002)
4-7-4: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, clause, provision or portion of this chapter shall
be held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, or the applicability thereof to any person, substance or product
is held invalid, such holding shall not affect any other section, subsection,
clause, provision or portion of this chapter or any other person, substance or
product covered by the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1379, 9-27-2002)
4-7-5: PENALTY:
The processing of each wild game carcass without the license referenced herein
shall constitute a separate offense which shall subject the violator to a fine
not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each separate
violation. (Ord. 1379, 9-27-2002; amd. 2010 Code)
CHAPTER 8
VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
4-8-1: Video Gaming Permitted
4-8-2: License Required; Application
4-8-3: Fees
4-8-4: Privilege
4-8-5: Regulations
4-8-6: Video Gaming Cafes
4-8-1: VIDEO GAMING PERMITTED:
   A.   Video gaming, as defined by the Illinois Video Gaming Act, 230 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., is permitted in the City subject to the
provisions of this chapter.
   B.   Video gaming is not permitted within the City except pursuant to the
issuance of a Class J liquor license to the holder of a Class A, C, or D
license as set forth in section
4-2-11 of this title, and pursuant to the issuance of a valid gaming terminal
license as set forth in section
4-8-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 1739, 2-12-2019)
4-8-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
A Class J licensed establishment must apply for and obtain a valid gaming
terminal license from the Mayor of the City for each video gaming terminal to
be operated on a licensed premises. Information about the location and
operation of the video gaming terminals must be submitted with the application,
along with a copy of the licensee's State video gaming license issued by the
Illinois Gaming Board, and payment of the gaming terminal fee required by this
chapter. (Ord. 1739, 2-12-2019)
4-8-3: FEES:
An annual fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) is hereby imposed on each video
gaming terminal operated within the City. The annual fee must be paid at the
time of submission of an application for a video gaming license, and annually
thereafter. (Ord. 1739, 2-12-2019)
4-8-4: PRIVILEGE:
A video gaming license is purely a personal privilege and does not constitute
property nor is it transferable. (Ord. 1739, 2-12-2019)
4-8-5: REGULATIONS:
The following regulations apply to all licensed establishments operating a
video gaming terminal on the licensed premises:
   A.   A valid State video gaming license must be clearly displayed at all
times.
   B.   A valid City video gaming license must be clearly displayed at all
times.
   C.   No more than the maximum number of video gaming terminals allowed by
the Illinois Video Gaming Act 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq., may be located on the
licensed premises.
   D.   All video gaming terminals must be located in an area restricted to
persons over twenty one (21) years of age. The entrance to the restricted area
must be within the view of at least one employee of the establishment who is
over twenty one (21) years of age. Any licensed establishment that allows
persons under twenty one (21) years of age to enter the establishment must
isolate video gaming terminals in a separate area inaccessible to minors.
   E.   No licensed establishment may permit any person under the age of twenty
one (21) years to use, play, or operate a video gaming terminal.
   F.   Signage must be posted at the entrance to, and inside of, the
designated gaming area in accordance with the regulations adopted by the
Illinois Gaming Board.
   G.   The licensed establishment must fully comply with all applicable City
ordinances, including the City's liquor control regulations, as well as any
applicable Federal and State laws and regulations.
   H.   The licensed establishment must fully comply with the Illinois Video
Gaming Act, as amended, and all rules, regulations, and restrictions imposed by
the Illinois Gaming Board.
   I.   Licensed establishments must immediately notify the Mayor in the event
the Illinois Gaming Board revokes or suspends the licensed establishment's
video gaming license. The revocation, loss, or suspension of a valid State
video gaming license shall automatically result in the revocation, loss, or
suspension of the City video gaming license for all video gaming terminals
without any refund of any fee.
   J.   An owner, manager, or employee over the age of twenty one (21) must be
present during all hours of operation when video gaming terminals are available
for use by the public. (Ord. 1739, 2-12-2019; amd. Ord. 1768, 7-13-2021; Ord.
1768, 7-13-2021)
4-8-6: VIDEO GAMING CAFES:
Video gaming cafes are not permitted in the City. A "video gaming cafe" is
defined as an establishment whose primary or major focus is video gaming, and
the service of alcohol and food is secondary to the video gaming operation. The
following factors may be considered when determining if a proposed or operating
establishment is a video gaming cafe:
   A.   The layout and design of the establishment;
   B.   The preparation and variety of food and beverages offered;
   C.   The creation and operation of a commercial kitchen on the premises
where gaming is situated or a partnership with an establishment that operates a
commercial kitchen;
   D.   Whether the number of video gaming machines relative to the customer
seating capacity of the establishment is less than ten (10) customer seats to
one machine;
   E.   Whether the square footage of space devoted to video gaming relative to
the amount of space devoted to other activities is less than four (4) square
feet for non-gaming to one square foot for gaming;
   F.   The source of proposed or actual revenue derived from the
establishment;
   G.   Whether the establishment is proposed to be marketed as a gaming
establishment or have a gambling theme;
   H.   The number of employees at the establishment and their proposed
function; and
   I.   Any other factors as deemed relevant by the Mayor. (Ord. 1739, 2-12-
2019)
BUSINESS REGISTRATION
SECTION:
4-9-1: Definitions
4-9-2: Business Registration Required
4-9-3: Fee; Late Fee
4-9-4: Duration
4-9-5: Registration Not Assignable; Unlawful Use
4-9-6: Application For New And Existing Businesses And Organizations
4-9-7: Registration Renewal
4-9-8: Suspension, Revocation, And Appeal
4-9-9: Penalty
4-9-10: Enforcement Of Other Ordinances
4-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, unless otherwise required, the following words shall
have the meaning hereinafter ascribed to them:
                                 Any for-profit business operated by a sole
                                 proprietor, partnership, limited partnership,
                                 corporation, limited liability company, joint

                                 A period of three or less business days,
