                                 referring to the location of any Business
                                 within the City. (Ord. 1806, 12-12-2023)
 
4-9-2: BUSINESS REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
   A.   Any business domiciled in the City, conducting, or desiring to conduct
business from a location within the City shall register said business with the
City.
   B.   Any exempt organization sponsoring, conducting, and managing
entertainment festivals, tourist events, or agricultural or seasonal markets,
such as a farmer's market, in the City shall register with the City prior to
the event for informational purposes only, but is not required to pay a
registration fee.
   C.   Food trucks operating from one or more locations within the City for
more than a temporary period shall register said business with the City. (Ord.
1806, 12-12-2023)
4-9-3: FEE; LATE FEE:
   A.   The annual registration fee is twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and shall
be submitted with the registration application or renewal affidavit. This fee
is non-refundable and is used solely for the administration of this Title 4.
   B.   A late fee of five dollars ($5.00) per month or part of a month shall
be due with any renewal registration application or renewal affidavit filed
after May 31st of each year. (Ord. 1806, 12-12-2023)
4-9-4: DURATION:
Each business shall be registered no later than May 31st of every year.
Registrations are effective for one (1) registration year, as defined herein,
or for the balance of the registration year if the application is filed for a
new business after May 31st of any year.
   A.   The City Clerk shall notify each registered business of registration
expiration each year during the months of March and April. However, it is the
obligation of each business to renew its registration and failure to receive an
expiration notification is not a defense for operating without being
registered.
   B.   The City Clerk shall issue a certificate of registration for each
registered business. This certificate shall be posted in a prominent visible
location in each business. (Ord. 1806, 12-12-2023)
4-9-5: REGISTRATION NOT ASSIGNABLE; UNLAWFUL USE:
No registration granted under the provisions of this Chapter may be assigned or
transferred. Each registration is only valid for the owner or owners filing the
application and for the business location named in the registration. The
purchaser or purchasers of an existing business shall file a new application
for registration no less than seven (7) business days prior to completing the
purchase. (Ord. 1806, 12-12-2023)
4-9-6: APPLICATION FOR NEW AND EXISTING BUSINESSES AND ORGANIZATIONS:
   A.   Each registration application shall be submitted by the business owner
or owners or the exempt organization's authorized representatives to the City
Clerk in writing on a form provided by the City Clerk and include the
registration fee, except as stated in Section
4-9-2 (B) above.
   B.   Each application will contain no less than the following information:
      1.   Business name, address, and telephone number, and type of business
entity.
      2.   Business owner or owner's names, addresses, and telephone numbers.
      3.   Exempt organization's authorized representatives and evidence of
authorization.
      4.   Description of business activity, services performed, and/or goods
to be sold.
      5.   Property owner(s) names, addresses, and telephone numbers, if
different than business owners.
      6.   Additional contact name(s) and telephone number(s) ie. manager or
key employee.
      7.   An after hours (emergency) contact name and telephone number.
      8.   Date business began or anticipates beginning operations in the City.
      9.   Hours of operation.
      10.   The certificate of license number issued under the Illinois
Retailers Occupation Tax Act, Service Occupation Tax Act, and/or Use Tax Act,
if applicable.
      11.   Federal Income Tax Identification Number.
      12.   Type and location of any toxic, flammable, or hazardous materials
stored or used at said location, if the quantity is a reportable amount under
state laws or regulations.
      13.   Name, type, and contact information for any security alarm/company
on premises.
   C.   Every application for a food-related business, including food trucks,
shall provide evidence of the required food preparation or other health
certificates issued by the Jersey County Health Department, or applicable
health department for food trucks.
   D.   Any business required by law to be bonded or insured shall provide
evidence of such bond or insurance.
   E.   Significant changes to the original information submitted which occur
during the registration year shall be reported to the City Clerk as soon as
possible, and the registration will be amended at no additional charge to the
registrant.
4-9-7: REGISTRATION RENEWAL:
Registration renewal may be accomplished by affidavit signed by the owner of a
business or an authorized representative of an exempt organization on a form
provided by the City stating that no change in registration information has
occurred. (Ord. 1806, 12-12-2023)
4-9-8: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION, AND APPEAL:
   A.   The City Clerk, upon approval of the mayor, is hereby authorized to
suspend or revoke a Business Registration thereby causing the cessation of a
business, when:
      1.   The business operation constitutes a clear and present danger to the
public safety, health, or general welfare; or
      2.   The registration application information is fraudulent, false,
incomplete, or deceptive; or
      3.   The business fails to pay all applicable fees or taxes imposed by
the City or State of Illinois.
   B.   If a registration is suspended or revoked the City Clerk will issue a
written notice to the business owner to be delivered by a police officer of the
City, or served by certified mail return receipt requested, at the business
address supplied by the owner. The notice will include the reason or reasons as
outlined above in (A) (1) through (3) that caused the action. A suspension or
revocation shall remain in place unless rescinded by the City Clerk, upon
approval of the mayor, or reinstated by a successful appeal to the City
Council.
   C.   An appeal of the suspension must be requested by the registrant and
filed with the City Clerk within three (3) business days after receipt of the
notice and will be heard at:
      1.   The next regularly scheduled City Council meeting, provided that the
notice of appeal has been filed three (3) business days prior to the next
scheduled meeting, or
      2.   The meeting immediately following the notice of appeal should the
time constraints listed in (1) above not be met, or
      3.   A special meeting of the City Council, if requested by the business
owner, provided that the special meeting must comply with City ordinances, meet
public notice requirements, and be no less than five (5) business days' notice.
   D.   The City Attorney, or a designated attorney representative, shall
present the complaint and represent the City. The registrant is allowed counsel
and has the right to submit evidence and cross-examine witnesses. A two-thirds
corporate majority vote of the City Council is required to rescind or continue
the suspension or revocation.
   E.   The City will keep an electronic record of the hearing. If either party
requires a transcript that party shall pay the cost of the transcription.
   F.   Revocation of a business registration shall not preclude prosecution or
imposition of other penalties for the violation of any other ordinance of the
City. (Ord. 1806, 12-12-2023)
4-9-9: PENALTY:
Any business, except an exempt organization, operating in violation of this
Chapter, once notified in writing by the City Clerk of the violation may be
fined two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day for each offense. Each
calendar day of operation of a business without the requisite certificate shall
be considered a separate offense. (Ord. 1806, 12-12-2023)
4-9-10: ENFORCEMENT OF OTHER ORDINANCES:
Any business issued a registration certificate must comply with all other City
ordinances. By issuing a registration certificate the City has not waived the
full enforcement of any other ordinances nor is the possession of a valid
registration a defense to any other violation. (Ord. 1806, 12-12-2023)
TITLE 5
HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
CHAPTER 1
NUISANCES
SECTION:
5-1-1: Nuisances Enumerated
5-1-2: Authority To Complain
5-1-3: Abatement Proceedings Generally
5-1-4: Emergency Abatement
5-1-1: NUISANCES ENUMERATED:
Within the city, it is hereby declared a nuisance for any person:
   A.   Common Law Nuisances; Nuisances In Fact: To cause any of those acts or
omissions that are declared to be nuisances by the laws of the state, and such
as are known as nuisances to the common law, not hereinafter enumerated in this
section or this code, or to cause those acts or omissions which are nuisances
in fact.
   B.   Nuisance Defined By Code: To cause any of those acts or omissions that
are declared by this code to be nuisances.
   C.   Continuing Violations Of Code: To continue to do any act, acts,
omission or omissions which constitute a violation of this code or other
ordinance of the city.
   D.   Licenses; Failure To Obtain: To fail or refuse to obtain and possess
any license required by this code or other ordinance of the city.
   E.   Zoning Violations: To violate the zoning ordinance of the city.
   F.   Violation Of Technical Codes: To cause, allow, permit or suffer the
violation of the building code of the city, the electrical code of the city,
the fire prevention code of the city, the plumbing code of the city, or any
other technical code adopted by any provision of this code or any other
ordinance of the city.
   G.   Dangerous, Unsightly Structures Or Streets: To maintain any building,
structure, street, sign or billboard in an unsafe, hazardous or unsightly
condition.
   H.   Offensive Businesses: To carry on, use or occupy any distillery or
slaughtering establishment, or establishment for steaming or rendering lard,
tallow, offal, dead animals or other substance of like nature, without the
permission of the city council.
   I.   Odors: To engage in any activity which causes or produces unreasonably
offensive odors; except, that this subsection shall not apply to those
activities carried on in the public interest.
   J.   Unhealthy Conditions:
      1.   To maintain or permit any substance on the premises which is, or may
become, putrid or create an unhealthy condition.
      2.   To create, allow, maintain or permit any condition which may
endanger the public health.
   K.   Noise 1 : To cause or allow unreasonably loud noises tending to cause
alarm or to disturb the public peace and quiet.
   L.   Attractive Nuisances: For the owner or occupier of any premises to
create, maintain or suffer an attractive nuisance to remain on the premises.
(1996 Code § 19-1)
   M.   Encroachments: To cause, allow, permit or suffer any encroachment upon
public ways or upon public grounds, except as provided in section
8-1-6 of this code. (1996 Code § 19-1; amd. 2010 Code)
   N.   Unlawful Assemblies 2 : To organize, lead or participate in any
unlawful assembly of persons. (1996 Code § 19-1)
   O.   Abandoned Containers 3 : To abandon or discard in any place accessible
to children any refrigerator, icebox or ice chest of a capacity of one and one-
half (11/2) cubic feet or more, which has an attached lid or door which may be
opened or fastened shut by means of an attached latch, or being the owner,
lessee or manager of such place, to knowingly permit such abandoned or
discarded refrigerator, icebox or ice chest to remain there in such condition.
(1996 Code § 19-1; amd. 2010 Code)
   P.   Littering 4 : To allow, suffer, permit or cause to be dropped, thrown,
discarded, placed or deposited on any public way or public place, or on any
private property when public property may be affected thereby, any paper,
glass, plastic, wood, metal, solid or liquid vegetable or animal compound,
rubbish, garbage, waste, effluent, junk, debris, litter, or solid, or any
combination thereof, except in a refuse receptacle or landfill site of the
city.
   Q.   Graffiti: To place graffiti upon the property of another, whether
publicly or privately owned, real or personal.
      1.   Definition: For the purpose of this subsection, "graffiti" is
defined as any sign, symbol, marking, drawing, name, initial, word, diagram,
sketch, picture, or letter, or combinations thereof, placed without the express
written permission of the owner, upon the real or personal property of said
owner.
      2.   Placement With Owner's Permission: It shall be unlawful for an owner
and/or occupant of property which is in the public view to place or give
permission to place any graffiti on said property if such graffiti incites
violence or the furtherance or proliferation of gang activity by reference to
gang or criminal activity, depicts or expresses obscenity by referring to
sexual activity, or contains defamatory material about a public or private
person or group.
      3.   Removal Required: Upon notification by the city, the owner of
property upon which graffiti has been illegally placed shall remove the
graffiti within five (5) working days of the date of notification. Failure to
remove graffiti within the specified time shall cause summary abatement of the
nuisance, and cost therefor shall be assessed to the owner.
      4.   Compensation And Restitution: The owner of the property shall be
entitled to restitution and compensation for the direct cost incurred in the
repair and restoration of his property to its previous condition from any
person convicted of the offense listed in this subsection; provided, that the
property owner submits receipts or other evidence of the costs for the removal
or repair of the graffiti; and provided further, that the court enters an order
of restitution.
      5.   Responsibility Of Parent Or Guardian:
         a.   The parent or legal guardian of a juvenile who resides with such
parent or legal guardian is liable for actual damages for the wilful or
malicious acts of such juvenile which cause injury to a person or property. The
juvenile shall be deemed to have committed the offense with the knowledge,
consent, acquiescence and permission of the parent or legal guardian in
violation of this subsection.
         b.   The parent or legal guardian shall be liable for the fine and
requirement of restitution or reparation imposed by a court upon a juvenile
defendant for violation of this subsection.
         c.   The sanctions of this subsection Q5 shall apply after said parent
or legal guardian shall have received a written notice thereof, either by
certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service
with a certificate of personal service returned, from the police department of
the city prior to the institution of any judicial sanction or penalty.
         d.   In any action brought pursuant to the provisions of this
subsection, the parent or legal guardian shall be made a party defendant. (1996
Code § 19-1)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  6-5A-4 of this code.
2 2. See also subsection 6-5A-6A of this code.
3 3. See also section
  6-6-3 of this code.
4 4. See also section
  5-2-3 of this title.
5-1-2: AUTHORITY TO COMPLAIN:
The following shall have standing to complain of any condition declared to be a
nuisance by this chapter:
   A.   The city.
   B.   Any person whose interests, rights or property are particularly
adversely affected by the nuisance. (1996 Code § 19-2)
5-1-3: ABATEMENT PROCEEDINGS GENERALLY:
Any person having standing to complain of a nuisance under this chapter, or the
head of any city department having cognizance of a nuisance, shall report the
fact of the nuisance and the details surrounding it to the city attorney, who
shall, if it is justified under the circumstances, institute abatement
proceedings in accordance with the laws of the state. (1996 Code § 19-3)
5-1-4: EMERGENCY ABATEMENT:
When a nuisance, as defined by this chapter, exists and the nuisance causes or
threatens imminent danger or great peril to persons or property, the nuisance
may be immediately abated by the city, by using the following procedure:
   A.   The mayor shall find that the nuisance exists, and that the nuisance
causes or threatens imminent danger or great peril to persons or property, and
that an emergency exists.
   B.   A copy of the mayor's findings made under subsection A of this section
shall be placed on file in the office of the city clerk.
   C.   The city clerk shall immediately issue a notice directed to the owner
or occupant of the premises on which the nuisance exists, directing the owner
or occupant to immediately abate the nuisance.
   D.   The notice issued pursuant to subsection C of this section shall be
served upon the owner or occupant of the premises upon which the nuisance
exists. The notice may be served by any officer or employee of the city. In the
event that the owner or occupant of the premises is not to be found, the notice
may be posted on the premises on which the nuisance exists.
   E.   Upon being served with a notice to abate a nuisance as provided in
subsection D of this section, the owner or occupant of the premises on which
the nuisance is located shall immediately abate the nuisance. The failure of
the owner or occupant to immediately abate the nuisance upon service or posting
of the notice shall be a violation of this code, and shall be punishable as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
   F.   In the event that the owner or occupant of a premises upon which a
nuisance is ordered to be abated under this section does not immediately abate
the nuisance, the appropriate city department shall immediately abate the
nuisance. The cost of the abatement by the city shall be assessed against the
property on which the nuisance existed, and shall be collected as other special
assessments. (1996 Code § 19-4)
CHAPTER 2
SOLID WASTE
SECTION:
5-2-1: Businesses; Containers And Use Required
5-2-2: Deposits At Collection Sites
5-2-3: Littering Prohibited
5-2-4: Private Collectors
5-2-1: BUSINESSES; CONTAINERS AND USE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or pile any wooden, pasteboard or
paper boxes, paper, trash, refuse or garbage adjacent to any place of business
along the alleys and streets without first providing a metal container, wooden
bin or wire pen, with a top covering thereon to cover the wooden, pasteboard or
paper boxes, paper, trash, refuse or garbage. (1996 Code § 12-1)
5-2-2: DEPOSITS AT COLLECTION SITES:
   A.   City Residents Only: Only residents of the city are entitled to dump or
deposit trash in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated by the
city regarding dumping at city collection sites.
   B.   Permit Required: Any city resident who desires to dump or deposit trash
at any collection facility of the city must purchase and display a city dumping
permit. It shall be unlawful to dump or deposit trash at any collection
facility without displaying a permit. (Ord. 1432, 3-30-2004)
   C.   Proof Of Residency And Cost Of Annual Permit: Permits are available for
purchase at city hall by residents of the city of Jerseyville only, and proof
of residency must be supplied before purchase can be made. Annual permits are
valid from May 1 of each year to April 30 of the following year. The cost of
said permit will be a yearly fee which will be reduced to half price if
purchased on or after November 1. Replacement fee will be charged for lost
permits, with proof of the original purchase of a permit. A fee schedule will
be established prior to the beginning of each fiscal year by the city council
which will be on file in the city clerk's office. (Ord. 1549, 3-23-2010)
5-2-3: LITTERING PROHIBITED 1 :
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, place or leave any ashes,
dirt, garbage, filth or other rubbish in or upon any street, alley or sidewalk,
or to knowingly suffer or permit such refuse to be thrown, placed or left in or
upon any street, alley or sidewalk.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw any paper or litter of any
kind from a vehicle into any street, alley or grounds in the city or to cause
any vehicle to be so loaded that in the hauling thereof any part of the load
shall be scattered or dropped in any street, alley or place of the city 2 .
(1996 Code § 12-2)

1 1. See also subsection 5-1-1P of this title.
2 1. See also section

5-2-4: PRIVATE COLLECTORS:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any
vehicle, including wagons, motor vehicles and vehicles propelled by human
power, for the hauling or carrying of any trash or any wooden, pasteboard or
paper boxes, paper, refuse or garbage for hire, unless a license for the
vehicle is first obtained as provided in this section. (1996 Code § 12-26)
   B.   Application For License: Application for a license required by this
section shall be made to the city clerk and shall state the name of the person
that will own and use the vehicle sought to be licensed, and the nature of the
material to be hauled and carried. (1996 Code § 12-27)
   C.   License Fee: The annual fee for a license required by this section
shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such commercial vehicle licensed. The
fees shall be paid to the city clerk, who shall remit them to the city
treasurer forthwith; however, no license fee shall be required for any vehicle
used to haul trash, refuse or garbage by any private individual not making any
charge for the use of the vehicle and not holding out the vehicle for hire.
(1996 Code § 12-28)
   D.   Issuance Of License; Records: The city clerk shall issue the license
required by this section and shall give the mayor a list of the licenses so
issued. (1996 Code § 12-29)
   E.   Term Of License: A license issued pursuant to this section shall be
valid for a period of one year next following its issuance. (1996 Code § 12-30)
   F.   Vehicles:
      1.   Covering Vehicles Required: All vehicles subject to this section
shall be used only when the vehicle has a top or covering on the body of the
vehicle adequate to prevent any trash or any wooden, pasteboard or paper boxes,
paper, refuse or garbage from falling from the vehicle into the street or other
public property of the city 1 . (1996 Code § 12-17)
      2.   Inspections: It shall be the duty of the mayor to make or cause to
be made such inspections of the vehicles subject to this section as may be
necessary to assure compliance with this section. (1996 Code § 12-18)
   G.   Revocation Of License: Any license issued pursuant to this section may
be revoked by the mayor for any violation of this section, which revocation
shall be in addition to any other penalty imposed for the violation. (1996 Code
§ 12-31)

1 1. See also section
  7-6-11 of this code.
CHAPTER 3
JUNK
SECTION:
5-3-1: Definitions
5-3-2: Nuisance Declared; Exemptions
5-3-3: Abatement Proceedings
5-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed
to them in this section:
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle from which, for a period of seven
(7) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, altered,
damaged, or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven
under its own motor power. "Inoperable motor vehicle" shall not include a motor
vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its
own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations.
JUNK, TRASH AND REFUSE: Any and all waste matter, whether reusable or not,
which is offensive to the public health and safety or to the aesthetics of the
neighborhood, and is specifically intended to include, but not be limited to,
worn out, wrecked or abandoned motor vehicles, trucks, tractors, machinery of
any kind, or any parts thereof, old iceboxes, refrigerators and stoves.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Shall mean, but shall not be limited to, the following:
motorcycles, passenger automobiles, trucks of all types, semitrailers and all
other vehicles which are propelled other than by muscular power; however, this
chapter shall not apply to any automobile dealer and the motor vehicles in and
upon such dealer's business premises.
(1996 Code §§ 12-43, 12-44; amd. 2010 Code; Ord. 1588, 5-15-2012)
5-3-2: NUISANCE DECLARED; EXEMPTIONS:
   A. Declaration Of Nuisance:
      1.   The storing of junk, trash or refuse on private property within the
city, or any motor vehicle which is not currently licensed by the state or
operable as defined by section
5-3-1 of this chapter and which remains upon any street, alley, lot or premises
within the city, shall be deemed a nuisance. (Ord. 1588, 5-15-2012)
      2.   Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection A, if the trash or
refuse is raw garbage not in covered containers, including, but not limited to,
food materials, animal carcasses or parts thereof, or other raw waste, or if
the junk, trash or refuse collects rainwater resulting in standing water not in
covered containers, which remains on private property or on a street, alley,
lot, or premises within the city for a period in excess of seventy two (72)
hours, then it shall be deemed a nuisance. (Ord. 1502, 7-3-2007)
   B.   Display Of License: All licenses shall be openly displayed in a proper
manner as prescribed by the statutes of the state.
   C.   Exemptions From Provisions:
      1.   Nothing in this section shall apply to any motor vehicle that is
kept within a building. (1996 Code § 12-44)
      2.   This section shall not apply to persons engaged in the business of
automobile repair. Such persons shall be allowed to have inoperable motor
vehicles and parts to motor vehicles that would otherwise be deemed junk on the
premises for a period of ninety (90) days. Any inoperable motor vehicle or part
thereof shall be deemed junk if remaining on the premises longer than ninety
(90) days. (Ord. 1222, 12-16-1997)
      3.   This section shall not apply to operable historic vehicles over
twenty five (25) years of age.
      4.   This section shall not apply to a motor vehicle on the premises of a
place of business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles. (2010
Code)
5-3-3: ABATEMENT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Notice Requirements; Failure To Abate: The owner of a motor vehicle
declared by this chapter to be a nuisance, or the owner of the premises or the
occupant of the property who allows any storage on his property which is a
nuisance under this chapter, upon being notified in writing by any city officer
to abate or remove the item within a time to be specified in the written
notice, not less than four (4) days nor more than seven (7) days from the date
thereof, and who shall neglect or refuse to abate the nuisance, shall be guilty
of an offense, and shall be guilty of a separate offense for each day that the
nuisance shall be permitted or suffered to remain after the expiration of the
time fixed by the written notice for the abatement of the nuisance. (1996 Code
§ 12-45; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Abatement By City: The city may remove or abate a nuisance under this
chapter at the expense of the owner of the unlicensed motor vehicle or the
owner or occupant of the property when, upon being notified in writing of the
nuisance, the owner or occupant does not abate or remove the nuisance. (1996
Code § 12-46)
CHAPTER 4
OPEN BURNING
SECTION:
5-4-1: Definitions
5-4-2: Burning Of Certain Substances Prohibited
5-4-3: Burning Leaves
5-4-4: Other Permitted Fires
5-4-5: Penalties
5-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation and the enforcement
of this chapter:
AGRICULTURAL WASTES: Any refuse, except garbage and dead animals, generated on
a farm or ranch by crop and livestock production practices, including such
items as bags, cartons, dry bedding, structural materials and crop residues,
but excluding landscape wastes.
DOMICILE WASTE: Any refuse generated on single-family domiciliary property as a
result of domiciliary activities. The term excludes landscape waste, garbage
and trade waste.
GARBAGE: Refuse resulting from the handling, processing, preparation, cooking
and consumption of food or food products.
LANDSCAPE WASTE: Any vegetable or plant refuse, except garbage and agricultural
waste. The term includes trees, tree trimmings, branches, stumps, brush, weeds,
grass, shrubbery and yard trimmings.
OPEN BURNING: The combustion of any matter in such a way that the products of
the combustion are emitted to the open air without originating in or passing
through equipment for which a permit could be issued under section 9(b) of the
state air environmental protection act 1 .
REFUSE: Any discarded matter; or any matter which is to be reduced in volume,
or otherwise changed in chemical or physical properties, in order to facilitate
its discard, removal or disposal.
TRADE WASTE: Any refuse resulting from the operation of any trade, business,
industry, commercial venture, utility or service activity, and any government
or institutional activity, whether or not for profit. The term includes
landscape waste but excludes agricultural waste. (1996 Code § 11-3; amd. 2010
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 415 ILCS 5/9(b).
5-4-2: BURNING OF CERTAIN SUBSTANCES PROHIBITED:
As defined in this chapter, "agricultural wastes", "garbage", "domicile
wastes", "refuse", "landscape wastes" and "trade wastes" are prohibited from
any open burning activity within the city. (1996 Code § 11-3)
5-4-3: BURNING LEAVES:
   A.   Hours And Conditions: The open burning of leaves is permitted within
the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and dusk; however, such burning shall not
be injurious to human, plant or animal life, to health, or to property, nor
unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life or property of others.
   B.   Burning On Public Ways And Property Prohibited: It shall be unlawful
for any person to burn or cause to burn leaves on city streets or on city
property adjacent to city streets. (1996 Code § 11-3)
5-4-4: OTHER PERMITTED FIRES:
The following fires are also permitted:
   A.   The setting of fires to combat or limit existing fires, when reasonably
necessary in the judgment of the responsible government official.
   B.   The burning of fuels for legitimate campfire, recreational and cooking
purposes, or in domestic fireplaces, in areas where such burning is consistent
with other laws; provided, that no garbage shall be burned in such cases.
   C.   The burning of waste gases; provided, that in the case of refineries,
all such flares shall be equipped with smokeless tips or comparable devices to
reduce pollution.
   D.   Small open flames for heating tar, for welding, acetylene torches,
highway safety flares, and the like. (1996 Code § 11-3)
5-4-5: PENALTIES:
Penalties for violation of any provision of this chapter shall be in accordance
with section
1-4-1 of this code. (1996 Code § 11-3)
CHAPTER 5
WEEDS AND VEGETATION
SECTION:
5-5-1: Definition
5-5-2: Enforcement Officer
5-5-3: Height Restriction; Nuisance Declared
5-5-4: Dry Vegetation
5-5-5: Duty To Cut Weeds; Authority Of City
5-5-6: Abatement Proceedings
5-5-7: Costs Of Abatement; Lien Provisions
5-5-8: Chipping Service
5-5-9: Penalty
5-5-1: DEFINITION:
"Weeds", as used in this chapter, shall include burdock, ragweed (giant),
ragweed (common), thistle, cockleburs, jimson, blue vervain, common milkweed,
wild carrot, poison ivy, wild mustard, rough pigweed, lamb's quarters, wild
lettuce, curled dock, smartweeds (all varieties), poison hemlock, and wild
hemp. (1996 Code § 28-16)
5-5-2: ENFORCEMENT OFFICER:
The code enforcement officer shall have the power and shall see that the
provisions of this chapter are properly enforced. (1996 Code § 28-19; amd. 2010
Code)
5-5-3: HEIGHT RESTRICTION; NUISANCE DECLARED:
   A.   All grasses, vegetation, and rank and growing weeds that are over eight
inches (8") in height are hereby declared a nuisance and shall be disposed of
as provided in this chapter. Common landscape vegetation and flowers and garden
vegetables and produce plants on the property, and in vegetable and flower
gardens of less than one-half (1/2) acre are exempt from this Height
Restriction.
   B.   In lieu of grass or allowing natural vegetation or weeds to grow on
property, the property owner may do all necessary actions to plant, fertilize,
and harvest (bale) alfalfa or sweet clover on property. The height requirements
in Section 5-5-3-A above shall be inapplicable to the property planted pursuant
to this paragraph, however the alfalfa or sweet clover shall be cut and baled
at least three (3) times per year and constitute more than fifty (50%) of the
vegetation on said lot. This paragraph shall not apply to single lots
containing less than one (1) acre, unless combined with one or more additional
adjacent and contiguous vacant lots totaling one (1) acre or more.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to spray or otherwise apply weed or
vegetation killer on any lot within the city limits or within the surrounding
one and one-half (1 1/2) mile limit governed by the city, in lieu of mowing
said lot. This prohibition shall not prevent spraying or application practices
used during normal lawn maintenance or for the purpose of partial or whole lawn
reseeding, as long as reseeding is completed within fourteen (14) days of the
date of spraying.
   D.   The first violation of Section 5-5-3-C shall result in a two hundred
fifty dollar ($250.00) fine, and all subsequent violations by the same person
shall result in a five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine. Fines are applicable to
both the landowner and the person applying the weed or vegetation killer, if
different." (1996 Code § 28-17; amd. Ord. 1777, 3-8-2022)
5-5-4: DRY VEGETATION:
All dry grass, weeds or other dry, dangerous, combustible material remaining
deposited or lying upon any property or premises within the city are hereby
declared a nuisance and a menace to public health and safety and shall be
disposed of as provided in this chapter. (1996 Code § 28-18)
5-5-5: DUTY TO CUT WEEDS; AUTHORITY OF CITY:
Every owner of real estate within the city shall cut weeds and other vegetative
growth, not including garden produce, grain or hay in process of drying, on his
property at all such times as may be necessary so that such weeds or other
vegetative growth shall not exceed eight inches (8") in height; and if real
estate abuts any public streets, roads or ways, the owner shall be responsible
for maintaining the area from the edge of the pavement or curb to his property
line, commonly known as the parkway, in compliance with this chapter; and if
said owner neglects or refuses to cut weeds or other vegetative growth so that
they exceed eight inches (8") in height, the city may cut them or authorize
some person to cut them on behalf of the city. However, no duty will be imposed
on parkways deemed unsafe by the city of Jerseyville. (Ord. 1589, 5-15-2012)
5-5-6: ABATEMENT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Abatement Required After Notice: Weeds and other vegetative growth, not
including garden produce, grain or hay in process of drying, over eight inches
(8") in height, or other combustible materials, such as are a public nuisance
under this chapter, shall be cut and removed by the owner, tenant, agent or
person having control of the premises within five (5) days after being served
by notice in writing by the code enforcement officer or the chief of police.
   B.   Service Of Notice: Service of the notice pursuant to subsection A of
this section may be by personal service, by first class certified mail to the
last known post office address of the owner, or by posting notice on the
property. Only one Service of Notice pursuant to this paragraph B per property
will be issued or posted per calendar year. All subsequent violations will be
addressed as described in paragraph 5-5-6-C.2. Abatement by City.
   C.   Failure To Abate:
      1.   Penalty: In conformity with state law, upon failure of the owner,
tenant, agent or person in charge of any premises within the city to cut,
destroy and remove weeds and other like growth which are nuisances within the
terms of this chapter, within the time designated by the notice to abate the
nuisance served pursuant to this chapter, and who shall neglect and refuse to
do so, shall be punished as prescribed in section
1-4-1 of this code and shall be subject to a like penalty for each day that the
nuisance shall be permitted or suffered to remain after the expiration of the
time fixed by the written notice for the abatement of the nuisance.
      2.   Abatement By City: In the event the owner, tenant, agent or person
in charge of a premises upon which a nuisance subject to this chapter exists
cannot be found, or fails to correct said nuisance, the code enforcement
officer or his assistant, on behalf of the city, may enter upon the premises
and proceed to cut, destroy and remove any weeds and similar growth at the
expense of the owner of the premises. This subsection C2 shall be construed as
full and complete power and authority for the city so to act. The code
enforcement officer shall report to the mayor and the city council from time to
time his actions in this respect and file a full and detailed statement of
premises so dealt with by him, the cost thereof, together with the name of the
owner, if the same can be ascertained.(1996 Code §§ 28-21 and 28-22; amd. 2010
Code; Ord. 1586, 5-1-2012; Ord. 1777, 3-8-2022)
5-5-7: COSTS OF ABATEMENT; LIEN PROVISIONS:
   A.   Charges Established: Charges for the abatement of the nuisance
described in this chapter shall be as follows:
      1.   The minimum charge for administrative cost shall be two hundred
dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 1347, 8-7-2001)
      2.   If city employees provide any labor, such labor shall be charged at
the rate of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per hour, per employee. This hourly
rate will increase one dollar ($1.00) per hour each year thereafter, beginning
on April 1, 2001. (Ord. 1347, 8-7-2001; amd. 2010 Code)
      3.   All costs for abating the nuisance, including, but not limited to,
all labor, expenses of abatement including the rental of any equipment or
disposal and other costs incurred by the city including reasonable attorney
fees. Abatement includes the cost of removing debris or litter, which may
include cutting the weeds or other vegetation.
      4.   The cost of any independent contractor hired by the city.
      5.   The costs of preparing the notice of violation and lien, recording
the lien, releasing the lien and determining the ownership of land.
   B.   Invoice; Nonpayment A Lien: Upon completion of the abatement of the
nuisance, the city shall prepare and deliver an invoice for all charges
attributable to abatement and related activity. In the event that said invoice
is not paid by the close of business thirty (30) days following the date of the
invoice, the city attorney shall prepare and file a lien against the property
where said abatement occurred.
   C.   Costs A Lien; Recording And Form: All of the above costs shall be a
lien against the property and a charge against the owner or occupants. The lien
shall be recorded with the county recorder of deeds as soon as practical after
the nuisance is abated and the invoice for such charges remain unpaid. The form
of the lien shall conform with the requirements of law. (Ord. 1338, 5-15-2001)
   D.   Enforcement Of Lien: Upon payment of the lien in full, including all
costs, expenses, attorney fees, and recording fees, and an additional release
recording fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), the lien shall be released by the city
or person in whose name the lien has been filed; and the release shall be filed
of record in the same manner as filing notice of the said lien. (1996 Code §
28-24; amd. 2010 Code)
5-5-8: CHIPPING SERVICE 1 :
The city may provide a chipping service for the citizens of the city in order
to improve the appearance of the city by providing for the safe and
environmental removal of trees and brush and prevent said materials from being
placed in landfills. The city is authorized to charge the fee set out in
section
8-1-9 of this code for said service. (1996 Code § 28-26; amd. 2010 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 8-1-9 of this code.
5-5-9: PENALTY:
In addition to being guilty of a nuisance subject to abatement as provided in
this chapter, any person who may permit, suffer or allow weeds or any
combustible material prohibited by this chapter to remain upon premises
occupied, owned or controlled by him or under his supervision or care to become
a menace to public health and safety, or create a nuisance, shall be punished
as prescribed in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1996 Code § 28-25)
CHAPTER 6
OAK GROVE CEMETERY; NEW CEMETERIES
SECTION:
5-6-1: Oak Grove Cemetery Established; Description
5-6-2: Plat Adopted
5-6-3: Supervision Of Cemetery
5-6-4: Sexton
5-6-5: Buildings And Fixtures
5-6-6: Lot Sales
5-6-7: Use Of Lots And Blocks
5-6-8: Deed Required For Burials
5-6-9: Graves And Grave Sites
5-6-10: Rules And Regulations For Care, Ornamentation And Use Of Lots
5-6-11: Grave And Lot Fees
5-6-12: Records Kept
5-6-13: Prohibited Acts
5-6-14: New Cemeteries
5-6-1: OAK GROVE CEMETERY ESTABLISHED; DESCRIPTION:
All of the following described real estate being situated in the county of
Jersey and state of Illinois and containing thirty (30) acres, more or less,
together with such additions as may be hereinafter made thereto for cemetery
purposes, shall be called and known by the name of "Oak Grove Cemetery". Said
premises are hereby declared to be the public burial grounds of the city and
are to be kept and controlled by the city council for cemetery purposes and
uses. (1996 Code § 7-16; amd. 2010 Code)
Commencing 12 rods east of the Southwest corner of the East Half (E1/2) of the
Northeast Quarter (NE1/4) of Section 21 in Township 8 North, Range 11 West of
the Third Principal Meridian; thence east on half-section line through said
section a distance of 40 rods; thence north 40 rods; thence west 40 rods;
thence south 40 rods, to the place of beginning; also the North Half (N1/2) of
the Southeast Quarter (SE1/4) of the Northeast Quarter (NE1/4) of said Section
21, in Township 8 North, Range 11 West of the Third Principal Meridian.
(1996 Code § 7-16)
5-6-2: PLAT ADOPTED:
The plat hereinbefore made, subdividing the cemetery grounds into blocks,
squares, lots and avenues designated and numbered, is hereby declared to be the
lawful plat of Oak Grove Cemetery; and the same shall not be changed except by
order of the city council. (1996 Code § 7-17)
5-6-3: SUPERVISION OF CEMETERY:
   A.   The premises of Oak Grove Cemetery shall be under the control and
supervision of the commissioner of public property of the city and the city
council. (1996 Code § 7-19)
   B.   The commissioner of public property and the sexton shall have the
control, superintendency and charge of Oak Grove Cemetery and its appurtenances
and shall supervise and direct the ornamenting, adorning, embellishing, laying
out and improving the grounds of said cemetery and avenues, walks and squares
therein, and for that purpose, may employ such labor as may be necessary;
provided, that the amount of money annually expended shall not exceed the
amount annually appropriated for cemetery purposes by the city council; and
provided further, that the city council shall not allow any claims for money to
be drawn out of the cemetery fund until the claim shall have been first
approved by the commissioner of public property. (1996 Code § 7-20)
5-6-4: SEXTON:
   A.   Appointment And Compensation: The commissioner of public property, with
the advice and consent of the city council, shall appoint a sexton over Oak
Grove Cemetery, who shall receive such compensation for his services as may be
determined by the city council. (1996 Code § 7-24; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Duties: The sexton shall:
      1.   Have charge of Oak Grove Cemetery and shall keep and preserve the
grounds, buildings and fences in good order and repair, and the monuments,
tombstones, shrubbery, and everything erected or placed within the cemetery for
ornament and otherwise, free from injury or defacement and the walks and
avenues clean, in good condition, and free from obstructions. (1996 Code § 7-
25)
      2.   Enforce the ordinances and rules and regulations adopted by the city
in relation to the cemetery and report all violations thereof to the proper
officers for prosecution. (1996 Code § 7-25; amd. 2010 Code)
      3.   Be subject to the orders and directions of the commissioner of
public property in his labors in and about the cemetery and shall obey his
orders and directions.
      4.   Keep a book in which he shall enter the name and sex of each body
interred in such cemetery, with the date of the death of the deceased, and the
number of the lot or square upon which the same shall be interred, which book
shall be subject to the examination of all and any persons interested therein
at all proper times. The book shall be furnished by the city and shall be
delivered by the sexton to his successor in office. (1996 Code § 7-25)
5-6-5: BUILDINGS AND FIXTURES:
The commissioner of public property may, by and with the consent of the city
council, cause to be erected or provided all such buildings, vaults or other
fixtures as may be necessary and proper for the convenient use of Oak Grove
Cemetery, and for that purpose, may employ such laborers or workers and
purchase or contract for such materials as he may deem necessary. (1996 Code §
7-21)
5-6-6: LOT SALES:
   A.   Authority To Sell; Procedure: The sales of lots for burial purposes
exclusively may be made by the sexton on behalf of the city; and upon payment
made to the city clerk of the purchase price money for the lot or lots
purchased, the mayor and the city clerk shall execute a deed for such lot or
lots to the purchaser. All lots so sold and conveyed shall be used for burial
purposes only, subject to the provisions of this chapter. (1996 Code § 7-18;
amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Appraisal Of Lots: The commissioner of public property shall appraise
the squares or lots which may remain unsold in Oak Grove Cemetery and shall
from time to time, when deemed expedient, reappraise such squares or lots as
may remain unsold. He shall cause a list of squares and lots appraised by him,
with the amount at which the lot or square is appraised set opposite thereto,
to be filed with the city clerk, and approved by the city council, and no
square or lot shall be sold for less than the appraisal affixed thereon by the
city council. (1996 Code § 7-22; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Selling Of Unplatted Ground: The unplatted ground of Oak Grove
Cemetery, or any portion thereof, shall not be sold or traded without the
unanimous consent of the city council. (1996 Code § 7-31)
5-6-7: USE OF LOTS AND BLOCKS:
The lots or blocks of Oak Grove Cemetery shall be reserved for the use and
possession of such families and persons, and such only as have heretofore or
shall hereinafter become the purchasers of the same to be used by them as
burial places for the dead, and for no other purpose or use whatever, all of
which shall be under the control of the city council. All owners of said lots,
or other persons, shall comply with the rules and regulations of the city
council in the interment or removal of bodies, and in the care, ornamentation
and use of the grounds thereof, and no deed or contract made with the city
shall prevent the exercise of such powers on the part of the city. (1996 Code §
7-28; amd. 2010 Code)
5-6-8: DEED REQUIRED FOR BURIALS:
No one will be permitted to have a burial in any lot in Oak Grove Cemetery
unless said person has a deed for same or has procured written permission from
the city clerk for said burial, approved by the commissioner of public
property. (1996 Code § 7-30)
5-6-9: GRAVES AND GRAVE SITES:
   A.   Location Restrictions; Approval Required: It shall be unlawful to dig
any grave in any walk, lane or avenue of the cemetery, and in like manner, to
dig any grave or bury any body in the cemetery without the consent of the
commissioner of public property or the sexton.
   B.   Grave Specifications: All graves in Oak Grove Cemetery shall be dug at
least five feet (5') deep.
   C.   Fencing, Vaults And Ornaments: All fencing, vaults or ornaments placed
by individuals on their lots shall be so built and placed as not to obstruct
any walk, lane or avenue, or access thereto. (1996 Code § 7-26)
5-6-10: RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR CARE, ORNAMENTATION AND USE OF LOTS:
The following rules are established in order that the maintenance of the
cemetery can be done with the least interference:
   A.   No tin cans, glassware or markers, other than stone or marble, shall be
placed on the lots; except, that hanging baskets will be allowed if they meet
the following requirements:
      1.   All rods must be at least one-half inch (1/2"), with reinforcement
wing in the ground.
      2.   Rod must be on the back side of the stone, with basket hanging above
the stone.
      3.   Anything not meeting these specifications will be removed and can be
recovered at the office.
   B.   No more than two (2) dwarf bushes on one lot (in the second addition to
the cemetery, the dwarf bushes must go in the middle of the lot).
   C.   No wire, nails or metal of any kind are to be placed in the cemetery
except for metal plaques properly erected by veterans' organizations.
   D.   No holes are to be dug in graves for flowerpots or containers of cut or
artificial flowers.
   E.   All Christmas decorations placed on the ground after October 15 will be
picked up March 1. The sexton has the sole discretion to remove any floral
display that becomes unattractive or uncared for. All decorations placed in
cemetery after March 1 must be placed on stones or in vases or urns until two
(2) weeks before Memorial Day. All decorations on the ground after Memorial Day
will be removed June 10. No more decorations may be placed on the ground until
October 15.
   F.   Urns not maintained will be removed.
   G.   Flags will be allowed to be displayed the entire year if properly
maintained. "Proper maintaining" is defined as placing the flag as close to the
stone as possible and keeping the flag presentable, and not being faded, ripped
or torn. During Memorial Day, personal flags are not to be placed in the
veteran holders so as to not interfere with the placement and removal of the
flags owned by that veteran organization.
   H.   In addition to the rules and restrictions set forth in subsections A,
B, C, D, E, F and G of this section, the following shall also apply to sections
D and E and Darr Addition:
      1.   All government markers must be placed at ground level.
      2.   All stones erected must have a minimum base size of one foot (1') in
width and three feet (3') in length and will not exceed a greater height than
sixty inches (60").
      3.   Slanted stones and beveled stones are allowed in these additions,
however, they must comply with the above dimensions. (Ord. 1255, 4-6-1999)
5-6-11: GRAVE AND LOT FEES:
   A.   Fee Schedule On File: The city clerk shall have on file the most recent
ordinance setting forth the current rates and fees for grave openings, lots and
services at Oak Grove Cemetery. Perpetual care shall be included for all
graves; however, perpetual care on graves purchased after July 27, 1976, shall
be as shown in the most recent ordinance on file with the city clerk.
   B.   Prepayments: Persons who have prepaid their funeral expenses prior to
January 2, 1992, would be exempt from this fee schedule as shown in said recent
ordinance. Funeral home directors will provide the city with a list of all
persons who have made prepaid funeral arrangements. The fee schedule that was
in effect on the date the prepaid funeral arrangements were made shall apply.
   C.   Public Aid Recipients: Fees for Illinois public aid recipients will be
one-half (1/2) of the established rate.
   D.   After Three O'Clock P.M. Fees: After three o'clock (3:00) P.M. fees
apply to all funeral cortege arriving at the cemetery after three o'clock (3:
00) P.M. (Ord. 1312, 3-21-2000)
   E.   Nonresident Fees: The fees for residents and nonresidents of the city
of Jerseyville shall be the same. (Ord. 1551, 5-18-2010)
   F.   Assessment For No Perpetual Care: An annual assessment may be collected
on each lot in Oak Grove Cemetery if perpetual care has not been paid on said
lot. (1996 Code § 7-29)
5-6-12: RECORDS KEPT:
The city clerk shall keep a record of the Oak Grove Cemetery grounds, in
numerical order, of the blocks or squares in each division, with separate
columns ruled therein for the entry of the amount of appraisal, the name of the
purchaser, the amount sold for, and the date of sale. An additional column
shall also be ruled for the entry of any reappraisal which may be made. When
any block, square, lot or part thereof shall be sold, the clerk shall make an
entry of the name of the purchaser, the amount for which sold, and the date of
sale opposite the number of the block, square or lot on the record. (1996 Code
§ 7-23)
5-6-13: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person:
   A.   To break down, deface, hack or in any manner injure the fence or
enclosures of Oak Grove Cemetery; or
   B.   To tear down, deface or in any manner injure any lot, enclosure,
tombstone, material erected at any grave, or any shrub, bush, flower or other
thing or ornament within the cemetery; or
   C.   To cut, hack or deface any trees or shrubs, or in any manner injure the
same, or any other thing belonging to or standing on or being within the
cemetery; or
   D.   To in any manner injure the grass, herbage, streets, walks, ornaments
or other thing in or belonging to the cemetery, whether private property or
belonging to the city; or
   E.   To leave open any gate or the enclosure of the same, or any private
burial place therein, the same being done wilfully, negligently or carelessly;
or
   F.   To engage in any sports or amusements; or
   G.   To turn any beast or animal therein; or
   H.   To conduct himself in a boisterous, rude or indecent manner; or
   I.   To use profane or indecent language or in any manner disturb any burial
party or individual being there for a lawful purpose; or
   J.   To shoot any gun, pistol or firearms within the limits of the cemetery.
(1996 Code § 7-27)
5-6-14: NEW CEMETERIES:
No cemetery or burying grounds shall be established within the city without
authority therefor from the city council. (1996 Code §§ 7-1, 7-29)
TITLE 6
POLICE AND PUBLIC SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
6-1-1: Department Established; Composition
6-1-2: Appointment Of Subordinate Personnel
6-1-3: Police Pension Fund
6-1-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION:
There is hereby established a police department for the city, which shall
consist of the chief of police and such number of subordinate police officers
and other personnel as the city council may from time to time authorize. (1996
Code § 24-1)
6-1-2: APPOINTMENT OF SUBORDINATE PERSONNEL:
The subordinate personnel of the police department shall be appointed by the
board of fire and police commissioners 1 . (1996 Code § 24-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 3 of this code; see section
  1-6-3 of this code for appointment of police chief.
6-1-3: POLICE PENSION FUND:
   A.   Fund Established: There is hereby established a police pension fund,
effective December 29, 1953, as provided by law.
   B.   Board Of Trustees Of Fund: The board of trustees of the police pension
fund established in subsection A of this section shall consist of five (5)
members, two (2) of whom shall be appointed by the mayor, two (2) of whom shall
be elected by the members of the police department and one of whom shall be
elected by the beneficiaries of the pension fund. The elections shall be held
biennially on the third Monday in April, and the term of each member shall be
for two (2) years. The pension board shall meet at least quarterly as provided
by law and shall hold such additional meetings as may be called by the
president of the pension board.
   C.   Contributions To Fund: There shall be deposited in the police pension
fund created in this section, the sums required by law, which shall include
9.91 percent per month deducted from the salary of each member of the police
force and the proceeds of any annual taxes and/or fees collected by the city as
provided in 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq. (1996 Code § 24-3;
amd. 2010 Code)
CHAPTER 2
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT
ARTICLE A. EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY
SECTION:
6-2A-1: Agency Established
6-2A-1: AGENCY ESTABLISHED:
Pursuant to 20 Illinois Compiled Statutes 3305/10, the mayor, with the advice
and consent of the city council, is hereby authorized to appoint a liaison
officer to facilitate the cooperation and protection of Jerseyville with Jersey
County emergency services and disaster agency. (1996 Code ch. 8, art. II)
ARTICLE B. CIVIL EMERGENCIES
SECTION:
6-2B-1: Definitions
6-2B-2: Proclamation Of Civil Emergency
6-2B-3: Imposition Of Curfew
6-2B-4: Emergency Orders
6-2B-5: Duration Of Proclamation; Renewal
6-2B-6: Unavailability Of Mayor; Order Of Command
6-2B-7: Effect Of Other Laws
6-2B-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed
to them:
CIVIL EMERGENCY: A. A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of
actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate
power to execute the threat, by three (3) or more persons acting together
without authority of law; or
   B.   Any natural disaster or manmade calamity, including flood,
conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the city,
resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to
such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public
health, safety and welfare.
CURFEW: A prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering, standing
or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises
within the city, except officials of any governmental unit and persons
officially designated to duty with reference to a civil emergency. (1996 Code §
8-41)
6-2B-2: PROCLAMATION OF CIVIL EMERGENCY:
   A.   Authority Of Mayor: Whenever a civil emergency exists, the mayor shall
proclaim the existence by means of a written declaration setting forth the
facts which constitute the emergency. (1996 Code § 8-42)
   B.   Notice Of Proclamation: Upon issuing the proclamation of a civil
emergency pursuant to this section, the chief of police shall notify the news
media situated within the city and shall cause three (3) copies of the
proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the
following places within the city: the city hall, the police station and the
post office. (1996 Code § 8-43)
6-2B-3: IMPOSITION OF CURFEW:
After the proclamation of a civil emergency by the mayor, he may order a
general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the city, or to the
city as a whole, as he deems advisable, which curfew shall be applicable during
such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interest of the
public safety and welfare. (1996 Code § 8-44)
6-2B-4: EMERGENCY ORDERS:
After the proclamation of a civil emergency as provided in this article, the
mayor may also, in the interest of public safety and welfare, make any or all
of the following orders:
   A.   Order the closing of all retail liquor stores, including taverns and
private clubs or portions thereof, wherein the consumption of intoxicating
liquor and beer is permitted.
   B.   Order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any
wholesaler or retailer.
   C.   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away
gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container
other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle.
   D.   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving
away of any firearm or ammunition of any character whatsoever.
   E.   Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection
of life and property. (1996 Code § 8-45)
6-2B-5: DURATION OF PROCLAMATION; RENEWAL:
The proclamation of a civil emergency authorized by this article shall be
effective for a period of forty eight (48) hours unless sooner terminated by a
proclamation of the mayor indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists.
The mayor shall have the power to reproclaim the existence of a civil emergency
at the end of each forty eight (48) hour period during the time the civil
emergency exists. (1996 Code § 8-46)
6-2B-6: UNAVAILABILITY OF MAYOR; ORDER OF COMMAND:
In any civil emergency or disaster subject to this article, if the mayor is not
available or is incapacitated, the first person available from the following
list, in order of descent, is to assume all the powers delegated to the mayor
by this article:
   A.   The commissioner of accounts and finances.
   B.   The commissioner of public property.
   C.   The commissioner of streets and public improvements.
   D.   The commissioner of public health and safety.
   E.   The chief of police. (1996 Code § 8-47)
   F.   The coordinator of ESDA. (1996 Code § 8-47; amd. 2010 Code)
6-2B-7: EFFECT OF OTHER LAWS:
Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to impair the powers
contained in this code giving powers to the police and fire departments, but
shall be construed together with existing ordinances now in effect for the
safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. (1996 Code § 8-48)
CHAPTER 3
FIREFIGHTERS
SECTION:
6-3-1: Training Program
6-3-2: Calls Outside City
6-3-3: Pension Fund And Board Of Trustees
6-3-1: TRAINING PROGRAM:
   A.   The commissioner of public affairs and the chief of the fire department
shall prepare a list of items that represent a working knowledge of the
equipment and procedures of the Jerseyville volunteer fire department. This
list is intended to be a basis for training that shall provide for a minimum
level of ability. Practice, training and experience beyond the minimum level of
ability is encouraged. (1996 Code § 11-5; amd. 2010 Code; Ord. 1547, 2-23-2010)
   B.   All firefighters shall complete the list by examination within four (4)
months of their becoming firefighters. The examining officer shall be the
chief, assistant chief, or a designated training officer. (1996 Code § 11-5;
amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Further training or recertification by the list may be required of a
firefighter at the discretion of the chief of the fire department.
   D.   Additions or corrections to this program may be enacted by the chief
upon discussion with, and vote of the firefighters. Any additions or
corrections will then be subject to the four (4) month period for completion by
each firefighter. (1996 Code § 11-5)
6-3-2: CALLS OUTSIDE CITY:
   A.   Calls Authorized: The fire department will answer fire alarms outside
the city limits when called upon by residents located within the boundaries of
the JEM Fire Protection Association, as long as an agreement for fire
protection services exists between the city and the association.
   B.   JEM Fire Call Boundaries: JEM fire call boundaries shall be as follows:
(1996 Code § 11-4; amd. 2010 Code)
      1.   Jerseyville townships: Township 8 North, Range 11 West and Township
9 North, Range 11 West of the Third Principal Meridian, all Sections except
portions of those Sections within the city limits of Jerseyville, Illinois, and
      2.   English township: Township 8 North, Range 12 West of the Third
Principal Meridian, Sections 1, 2, 11, 12, 13, 14, 23, 24, 25, 26, 35 and 36,
and
      3.   Mississippi township: Township 7 North, Range 11 West of the Third
Principal Meridian, Sections 1 through 16 and Sections 17 and 18 North of
McClusky Road. (2010 Code)
6-3-3: PENSION FUND AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES:
   A.   Fund Established: There is hereby created and established a
firefighters' pension fund in and for the city, in accordance with 40 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/4-101 et seq. (article 4 of the Illinois pension code).
   B.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the terms "firefighters"
and "board" or "board of trustees" are defined, respectively, as full time
firefighters or full time firefighters entitled to participate in the benefits
of the pension fund as provided by article 4 of the Illinois pension code and
the board of trustees of the pension fund.
   C.   Rights, Powers, Duties And Functions Of Board And Beneficiaries: The
rights, powers, duties and functions of the board of trustees and the members
thereof, as such, and the rights and benefits of the various beneficiaries of
the pension fund shall be and are hereby declared to be in accordance with the
law and particularly article 4 of the Illinois pension code and all amendments
thereto.
   D.   Appointment Or Election Of Board; Powers And Duties; Compensation: The
board shall be appointed and elected as therein provided and shall exercise
such powers and perform such duties that shall be required of them by law. All
monies and securities belonging to said fund shall be held by the city
treasurer subject to the order of the board of trustees of the pension fund. An
annual list of beneficiaries and report of funds shall be made as required by
law. Members of the board of trustees of the pension fund shall serve without
compensation. (Ord. 1481, 1-3-2006)
CHAPTER 4
ANIMAL CONTROL
SECTION:
6-4-1: Purpose
6-4-2: Definitions
6-4-3: Animal Control Officer
6-4-4: Running At Large
6-4-5: Abuse Of Animals
6-4-6: Noisy Animals
6-4-7: Dangerous, Vicious Animals
6-4-8: Diseased, Injured Animals
6-4-9: Disposal Of Dead Animals
6-4-10: Offensive Animals
6-4-11: Location Of Animal Houses And Premises
6-4-12: Condition Of Animal Houses And Premises
6-4-13: Excrement; Filth; Carcasses
6-4-14: Nuisance Abatement Proceedings
6-4-15: Animal Bites
6-4-16: Adoption Program
6-4-17: Kennels And Pet Shops
6-4-18: Penalty
6-4-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is adopted to regulate and control animals within the city. It is
also created to protect the individual property owner's rights to control that
which may be offensive and detrimental to his person or property. (1996 Code §
5-16)
6-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
ANIMAL: Shall refer to livestock such as cattle, swine, horses, mules, donkeys,
sheep, dogs, cats, goats, rabbits or other animals and fowl such as chickens,
turkeys, geese, pigeons, doves, ducks or other fowl.
CAT: Unless otherwise expressly designated, shall be construed to include both
males and females.
DANGEROUS ANIMAL: A lion, tiger, leopard, ocelot, jaguar, cheetah, margay,
mountain lion, lynx, bobcat, jaguarundi, bear, hyena, wolf or coyote, or any
poisonous or life threatening reptile.
KENNEL: Any lot or premises or portion thereof on which more than three (3)
dogs, or more than three (3) cats, or more than three (3) other household
domestic animals, excluding puppies, kittens, or other babies under six (6)
months of age, are kept or on which more than three (3) such animals are
boarded for compensation or kept for sale.
VICIOUS ANIMAL: Any animal that has, without provocation, attacked a human
being or other animal, or an animal that, by its behavior or physical
condition, constitutes an immediate and serious physical or health threat to
human beings or animals, or any animal which has previously attacked or bitten
any human being or other animal on two (2) or more reported occasions. (1996
Code §§ 5-17, 5-90; amd. 2010 Code)
6-4-3: ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER:
   A.   Enforcement Duties: The animal control officer shall enforce the
provisions of this chapter, and shall perform his duties under the supervision
of the chief of police and the mayor. He is hereby authorized to make all
necessary arrests in carrying out the provisions of this chapter. The duties of
the animal control officer shall be in addition to the enforcement by the
police department. (1996 Code § 5-56; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Monthly Reports: The animal control officer shall submit monthly
reports to the chief of police setting forth the number of animals impounded,
indicating the breed, sex and color, and the number of animals disposed of or
redeemed, the number of arrests made and/or warning tickets issued and the name
and address of any owner or keeper of animals involved. (1996 Code § 5-56)
6-4-4: RUNNING AT LARGE:
   A.   No domestic animal shall be allowed or permitted to run at large within
the city, and any animal running at large in the city may be impounded.
   B.   No domestic animal shall be placed by the owner or any other person in
charge or control thereof, or be permitted by such person, upon any sidewalk,
curbstone, grass plot or planting space of any street, park or other public
property unless retained by a leash, which shall be no longer than six feet
(6'). (1996 Code § 5-18; amd. 2010 Code)
6-4-5: ABUSE OF ANIMALS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to be cruel in any way to any
animal in the city. Any person who inhumanely beats, overloads, underfeeds or
abandons any animal shall be guilty of an offense.
   B.   Any person who shall keep or cause any animal to be impounded in any
pound or other place of shelter or confinement shall supply such animal during
confinement with a sufficient quantity of good and wholesome food and water and
adequate and clean bedding. (1996 Code § 5-19)
6-4-6: NOISY ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor or keep any animal which disturbs
the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. (1996 Code § 5-20)
6-4-7: DANGEROUS, VICIOUS ANIMALS:
   A.   Prohibited Unless Permitted For Parades And Exhibitions: It shall be
unlawful to permit any dangerous animal or vicious animal of any kind to run at
large within the city; exhibitions or parades of animals which are ferae
naturae in the eyes of the law may be conducted only upon securing a permit
therefor from the chief of police.
   B.   Authority To Kill: Members of the police department, and any other
person in the city, are authorized to kill any dangerous animal when necessary
for the protection of any person or property. (1996 Code § 5-21)
6-4-8: DISEASED, INJURED ANIMALS:
   A.   Diseased Animals Prohibited: No diseased or sickly animal, nor any
animal that has been exposed to any disease that is contagious among such
animals, shall be brought into the city or allowed to run at large, or be
exposed in any public place whereby the health of man or beast may be affected;
nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the
owner thereof, except under the supervision of the animal control officer or
the commissioner of public affairs.
   B.   Authority To Kill; Interference Prohibited:
      1.   Any animal being in any street or public place within the city and,
in the estimation of any police officer, the animal control officer, or the
commissioner of public affairs, appearing to be injured or diseased past
recovery for any useful purpose, and when the owner cannot be located, after a
reasonable attempt has been made to do so, or when such animal is not being
attended and properly cared for by the owner or some proper person to have
charge thereof for the owner, or not having been removed to some private
premises, may be deprived of life by the officer or as he may direct, and shall
thereafter, unless at once removed by the owner, be treated as any other dead
animal found on a street or place.
      2.   No person, other than a police officer, the animal control officer,
or the commissioner of public affairs, or a person authorized by contract or
otherwise, shall in any way interfere with such dead, sick or injured animal in
any street or place, unless to terminate its life as authorized by this
section; except, that the owner or person having control of such animal may
terminate the life thereof in the presence and by the consent of a police
officer, the animal control officer, or the commissioner of public affairs.
(1996 Code § 5-22; amd. 2010 Code)
6-4-9: DISPOSAL OF DEAD ANIMALS:
   A.   Prohibited Disposal: No person shall leave or throw into any place,
street or public water, or offensively expose or bury anywhere within the city,
the body, or any part thereof, of any dead or fatally sick or injured animal;
nor shall any person keep any dead animal, or any offensive meat, bird, fowl or
fish, in a place where it may be dangerous to the life or detrimental to the
health of any person. (1996 Code § 5-23)
   B.   Burial Or Removal From City: Any owner or anyone in charge or
possession of any animal which may have died within the city shall properly
bury the carcass thereof, or remove the carcass not less than one-fourth (1/4)
mile beyond the city limits within nine (9) hours after a request to do so by
the chief of police, any member of the police department, or the animal control
officer. (1996 Code § 5-23; amd. 2010 Code)
6-4-10: OFFENSIVE ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city or within one-fourth (1/4)
mile of the city to own, keep, maintain, or suffer or permit to be kept and
maintained or operated any pen, shed, stable, house, building, structure, yard,
kennel, lot or enclosure of any kind or character, wherein any animal is kept
or harbored, which animal may be offensive or nauseating to any person residing
in the vicinity thereof or to persons passing along any street or alley near
thereto. (1996 Code § 5-33)
6-4-11: LOCATION OF ANIMAL HOUSES AND PREMISES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any chicken
coop, dovecote, rabbit hutch or other yard establishment for the housing of
small animals or fowl, except dogs, closer than thirty feet (30') to the
nearest portion of any building occupied by or in any way used by human beings,
other than that dwelling occupied by the owner or keeper of the animals or
fowl, or closer than ten feet (10') to the property line of the lot on which
such animals or fowl are kept or permitted to be kept, except where the animals
or fowl are kept for sale within a bona fide produce market or commission house
and, while so kept, are confined in small coops, boxes or cages, or where the
animals or fowl are kept for purposes of research in a laboratory.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain, within seventy
five feet (75') of the nearest portion of any dwelling or other building
occupied by or in any way used by human beings, other than the dwelling
occupied by the person keeping the animals or fowl, more than fifteen (15)
chickens or other domestic fowl four (4) months old, or more than ten (10)
rabbits or other small animals over the age of four (4) months, or more than
twenty five (25) rabbits or other animals under the age of four (4) months,
except where the fowl, rabbits or other small animals are kept for sale within
a bona fide produce market or commission house and, while so kept, are confined
in small coops, boxes or cages, or where the animals or fowl are kept for
purposes of research in a laboratory.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain, within two
hundred feet (200') of the nearest portion of any dwelling or other building
occupied by or in any way used by human beings, other than that dwelling
occupied by the person, more than twenty five (25) chickens or other domestic
fowl four (4) months of age and/or one hundred (100) chicks or other domestic
fowl under four (4) months old, or more than fifty (50) rabbits or other small
animals under the age of four (4) months, except where the fowl, rabbits or
other small animals are kept for sale within a bona fide produce market or
commission house and, while so kept, are confined in small coops, boxes or
cages, or where said animals or fowl are kept for purposes of research in a
laboratory. (1996 Code § 5-34)
6-4-12: CONDITION OF ANIMAL HOUSES AND PREMISES:
   A.   Cleanliness And Sanitation:
      1.   Every coop, dovecote, rabbit hutch or other yard establishment for
keeping animals shall be kept so that no offensive, disagreeable or noxious
smell or odor shall arise therefrom to the injury, annoyance or inconvenience
of any inhabitant of the neighborhood.
      2.   All structures, pens, coops or yards in which animals or fowl are
kept or permitted to be kept shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary
condition at all times, devoid of all rodents and vermin, and free from
objectionable odors. The interior walls, ceilings, floors, partitions and
appurtenances of all such structures shall be whitewashed or painted annually.
The enclosed area of all such structures shall be constructed in such a way as
to be dry at all times on the inside.
      3.   Any person keeping, feeding or housing any animal or fowl shall keep
the crates, coops, houses, sheds, yards, premises and enclosures wherein the
animal or fowl may be in a good sanitary condition, disinfected from time to
time and free from objectionable odors and smells, and shall remove from day to
day the droppings or excretions so that they may not become objectionable,
offensive or a nuisance to those living in the neighborhood. (1996 Code § 5-36)
      4.   For the purpose of killing flies and other insects, all structures,
pens or coops where fowl are kept or permitted to be kept shall be sprayed with
an insecticide as frequently as necessary to prevent attraction of flies and
other insects.
   B.   Yards For Fowl: All yards or runways where fowl are kept or permitted
to be kept shall be spaded and then limed once every three (3) months.
   C.   Manure:
      1.   Storage Receptacle Required: Every coop, dovecote, rabbit hutch,
pen, shed, stable, house, building, structure, yard, kennel, lot or enclosure
of any kind or character, wherein any animal is kept or harbored, shall be
provided with a watertight and flytight receptacle for manure, of such
dimensions as to contain all accumulations of manure, which receptacle shall be
emptied sufficiently often and in such a manner as to prevent its becoming a
nuisance. The receptacle shall be kept securely covered at all times, except
when open during the deposit or removal of manure or refuse.
      2.   Accumulation Prohibited: No manure shall be allowed to accumulate
except in such a receptacle.
      3.   Disposal Requirements: All manure, when removed from the receptacle,
shall be buried with a covering of not less than six inches (6") of earth or,
if used as fertilizer, immediately thoroughly spaded into the ground, or shall
be removed from the property. (1996 Code § 5-24)
   D.   Commercial Establishments: No person shall keep, feed, house or
maintain within the city for commercial purposes any animal in such a manner or
under such conditions as to become offensive to persons living in the vicinity
or neighborhood where they may be so located or so as to become a nuisance.
(1996 Code § 5-35)
   E.   Inspections: The animal control officer or the commissioner of public
affairs may, at any reasonable time, inspect any premises and issue such orders
as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this section. (1996 Code §
5-36; amd. 2010 Code)
6-4-13: EXCREMENT; FILTH; CARCASSES:
   A.   No person shall cast, dump, accumulate, place or deposit any animal
excrement, manure, offal or filth, or any carrion, within one-fourth (1/4) mile
of the limits of the city.
