any street or alley with merchandise, fuel or other articles or property longer
than may be necessary in the diligent removal thereof. (1996 Code § 25-5)
8-1-7: WATER DRAINAGE OVER SIDEWALKS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to suffer or permit the water falling or
draining from any building owned by him or under his control to spread over the
sidewalk in front of or adjacent to the premises. (1996 Code § 25-8)
8-1-8: REMOVING GRADE OR CORNER STAKES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to purposely change or remove any stake,
post or stone placed or set to designate the corner or line of any lot or land,
street or alley, or to show the grade of any street, alley or sidewalk. (1996
Code § 25-7)
8-1-9: CHIPPING TREE LIMBS 1 :
   A.   Service Provided By City: The city is hereby empowered to provide a
service to city residents in the form of chipping tree limbs. Requests for such
service shall be made to the street department. (1996 Code § 25-9)
   B.   Fees:
      1.   Fees Established:
         a.   The city is authorized to charge a fee of one hundred twenty five
dollars ($125.00) for chipping limbs from a tree whose trunk is smaller than
one foot (1') in diameter.
         b.   The city is authorized to charge a fee of two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) for chipping limbs from a tree whose trunk is the diameter of
one foot (1') or more. (1996 Code § 25-9; amd. 2010 Code)
      2.   Payment Of Fees: Fees are required to be paid prior to the
performance of the service. In cases of a natural disaster due to ice or wind,
the city may waive said fees for a period of not more than thirty (30) days.
(1996 Code § 25-9)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5-5-8 of this code.
CHAPTER 2
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Permit Required; Penalty For Failure To Obtain
8-2-2: Application For Permit
8-2-3: Deposit Or Bond Required
8-2-4: Notice To Superintendent Of Permit Issuance
8-2-5: Supervision Of Work
8-2-6: Minimum Requirements
8-2-7: Restoration Of Excavated Area; Liability Of Permittee
8-2-8: Protection Of Excavations
8-2-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO OBTAIN:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make an excavation in a city street
without first obtaining a permit therefor as provided in this chapter. Failure
to obtain a permit as required may be punishable by a fine of up to two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) per day for each day the violation continues. (1996
Code § 25-19; amd. 2010 Code)
8-2-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Application for a permit required by this chapter shall be made in writing on a
form furnished by the city clerk. The application shall be made by the
contractor doing the excavation and shall contain a clear and exact description
of the property, the purpose for which the excavation is proposed to be made,
the nature and character of the water or sewer tap, if desired, and drains, if
any, proposed to be put in. (Ord. 1260, 5-4-1999)
8-2-3: DEPOSIT OR BOND REQUIRED:
   A.   Amounts Of Deposits: At the time of making an application for a permit
required by this chapter, the applicant shall deposit with the city the
appropriate sum as indicated below: (Ord. 1337, 5-15-2001)
 
Excavation through oil and chip road surface $ 850.00
Excavation through asphalt road surface      1,500.00
Excavation through concrete road surface     3,000.00
 
(Ord. 1337, 5-15-2001; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Retaining Deposit; Refunds; Insufficient Deposit:
      1.   The city shall have the right to hold the deposit for up to ninety
(90) days. At the end of said ninety (90) days, if the excavation has been
properly refilled, the city shall refund the sum deposited less fifty dollars
($50.00) for administrative costs.
      2.   In the event the excavation has not been properly refilled, the city
shall have the right to take the deposit and apply it to the cost of properly
refilling the excavation.
      3.   In the event the deposit is insufficient to cover the cost of
refilling the excavation, then the city shall have further rights as described
in this chapter.
   C.   Performance Bond In Lieu Of Deposit: A contractor making the excavation
may, in lieu of making the above deposit, submit a performance bond for work
involved, payable to the city for an amount up to two hundred thousand dollars
($200,000.00). (Ord. 1337, 5-15-2001)
8-2-4: NOTICE TO SUPERINTENDENT OF PERMIT ISSUANCE:
Upon the issuance of a permit required by this chapter, it shall be the duty of
the person to whom the permit is granted to present the permit to the
superintendent of streets and to notify him of the nature and character of the
excavation proposed to be made and the time proposed for the making thereof.
(1996 Code § 25-22)
8-2-5: SUPERVISION OF WORK:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the superintendent of streets to personally
superintend the making of an excavation subject to this chapter and the
backfilling thereof, and he shall cause all excavations so made to be
backfilled in the best possible manner and the pavement to be replaced as
nearly as possible to its original condition.
   B.   All workers engaged in the work of making excavations subject to this
chapter and the backfilling thereof shall at all times be under the direction
and control of the superintendent of streets. (1996 Code § 25-23)
8-2-6: MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Concrete Street Openings:
      1.   Concrete shall be sawed a minimum of three inches (3") deep before
concrete removal in an area as follows:
         a.   The minimum width of the section removed shall be four feet (4').
For cuts not involving the curb or just curb sections, the cut shall start at
the edge of the curb two feet (2') from the outside face and extend to the
nearest joint or centerline of the road, for a road with no longitudinal
joints.
         b.   For cuts involving just the curb, curb sections shall be removed
in lengths of eight feet (8') or from joint to joint, whichever is smaller.
         c.   For cuts extending beyond the centerline, the full section
between curbs, and an eight foot (8') wide minimum, shall be removed and
replaced.
      2.   Replacement of excavation shall consist of full depth sand or rock
backfill, to be jetted or mechanically tamped and approved by the street
department prior to replacing concrete.
      3.   Fresh concrete shall be pinned to existing concrete by boring no. 4
reinforcing bars at twelve inch (12") maximum centers at all sides of contact.
Rebar shall be bored a minimum of four inches (4") into existing concrete and
shall be embedded twelve inches (12") minimum into fresh concrete.
      4.   In the event of full width replacements, no. 4 reinforcing at twelve
inch (12") minimum spacing shall be placed across the trench and parallel with
the centerline of the road and extend the full width of the removed section.
   B.   Other Than Concrete Streets: Street openings on streets other than
concrete are to be sawed, chopped or axed out, not over thirty inches (30")
wide, unless permission is given. (1996 Code § 25-26)
8-2-7: RESTORATION OF EXCAVATED AREA; LIABILITY OF PERMITTEE:
If a property owner to whom a permit was issued pursuant to this chapter does
not properly refill the excavation and place the street in as good condition as
it was originally, the city may then repair the excavation and charge the
property owner for the labor and materials expended thereon. The city may apply
all or any part of the deposit made by the person to whom a permit was issued
to the cost of properly refilling the excavation. In the event the deposit is
not sufficient to adequately reimburse the city, then the city has the right to
file a civil action against the person to whom the permit was issued in order
to recover unreimbursed expenses, court costs and attorney fees. (1996 Code §
25-24)
8-2-8: PROTECTION OF EXCAVATIONS:
Whenever any person is engaged in making an excavation subject to this chapter,
if the excavation, when left exposed, would be dangerous to persons or
vehicles, the person to whom a permit is issued pursuant to this chapter shall
erect a fence or railing at the excavation or work in such a manner as to
prevent danger to persons, and shall so maintain such fence or railing until
such work is completed or danger removed. It shall also be the duty of such
person to place upon the railing or fence at sunset, suitable and sufficient
red or yellow lights and keep them burning through the night during the
performance of such work. (1996 Code § 25-25)
CHAPTER 3
CITY PARKS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Rules And Regulations For Parks Generally
8-3-2: Dolan Park; Hours
8-3-3: Carl "Jerry" Wittman/Lions Club Park; Parking
8-3-4: Wock Family Lake
8-3-1: RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR PARKS GENERALLY:
   A.   Rules And Regulations: Unless otherwise stated in this chapter, use of
the Jerseyville parks and their facilities shall be limited to and governed by
the following rules, regulations and restrictions:
      1.   Hours:
         a.   All parks shall be open to the public from seven o'clock (7:00)
A.M. until the hour of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. during Central Standard Time
and from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. until eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. during
Central Daylight Saving Time. (1996 Code § 21-1)
         b.   No person or group of persons shall be permitted to use such
parks or their facilities outside the limits of the foregoing hours without
having first secured a written permit for such use from the parks and
recreation board of the city or person in charge of the facility or designated
authority. (1996 Code § 21-1; amd. 2010 Code)
      2.   Refuse And Trash Deposits:
         a.   Containers for the deposit of refuse of all kinds are provided
throughout the parks. All users of the parks and their facilities shall deposit
their trash and refuse in such containers.
         b.   It shall be unlawful for any person using such parks or their
facilities to allow trash or other refuse to be thrown, scattered or otherwise
deposited upon the premises of the parks in other than a container designated
for such refuse.
      3.   Fires:
         a.   No fires shall be permitted in any area of the parks other than
in areas posted clearly permitting such fires and then only in grills or ovens
provided by the parks or in so called barbecue grills owned by the users.
         b.   No lawfully permitted fire shall be left unattended, and all
fires, lawfully permitted, shall be completely and thoroughly extinguished by
the persons using such fire before such persons shall leave the area.
      4.   Vehicle Operation:
         a.   No vehicle shall be operated within the confines of the parks,
except on regular roadways. (1996 Code § 21-1)
         b.   No minibikes, four-wheelers, three-wheelers, motor scooters or
go-carts shall be permitted, except on regular roadways. (1996 Code § 21-1;
amd. 2010 Code)
         c.   Vehicles shall be parked in such areas as shall be designated for
parking or along roadways so long as such parked vehicle shall not block any
such roadway or driveway. (1996 Code § 21-1)
      5.   Presence Of Liquor Or Drugs: No person shall bring within, possess,
drink, sell, or transfer any intoxicating liquors or drugs in the park system.
(1996 Code § 21-1; amd. 2010 Code)
      6.   Firearms: It shall be unlawful to discharge or carry upon the person
any firearm within the confines of the parks. For the purpose of this section,
a "firearm" shall be construed as including any device capable of discharging a
projectile for a distance of more than fifty feet (50') regardless of the means
used to propel such projectile.
      7.   Disturbing The Peace: No person shall make, aid, countenance, or
assist in making any loud, unusual, or improper noise, threat, fight,
disturbance, nuisance, breach of the peace, or diversion or tending to a breach
of the peace or disturbance of the peace and quiet in the park system, or be
guilty of any disorderly conduct therein, or collect with other persons, in
bodies or crowds, for unlawful purposes, or for any purpose to the annoyance,
obstruction or disturbance of other persons or lawful assemblage.
      8.   Profane, Indecent Language, Acts Or Publications: No persons shall
use any abusive, threatening, profane, indecent, or obscene language, or
language calculated to occasion a breach of peace; nor induce, commit, or
perform any indecent or obscene act or behavior; nor exhibit, possess or
transfer indecent or obscene pictures, writings or articles of any kind within
the park system.
      9.   Riding Horses: No person shall ride any horse, pony, or other
equestrian animal within the confines of the parks except upon regular
roadways.
      10.   Tampering With, Damage To Property: It shall be unlawful to
wilfully mark upon, deface, damage, destroy or remove any park facility or
property of any nature whatsoever.
      11.   Sleeping, Camping: No person shall place, erect, or use any
hammock, swing, tent, or shelter or otherwise camp or sleep in the park system
except such organizations who may have received written permission from the
director to do same. (1996 Code § 21-1)
      12.   Use Of Playground Equipment: No adult person shall in any manner
use any of the playground apparatus or devices meant exclusively for the use of
children. (1996 Code § 21-1; amd. 2010 Code)
      13.   Athletic Events; Amusements:
         a.   No person shall engage in games of softball or baseball except in
those parks which have established diamonds and backstops constructed for that
purpose.
         b.   No person shall engage in any sport, game or amusement in the
park system except at such places and times as may be designated by the
department and then only under such rules as are prescribed; nor shall any
person walk, remain, or conduct himself upon such portion of the park system
designated for any particular game, sport, or amusement in such way as to
interfere with the use of such portion by persons who are using the same for
the particular sport, game or amusement for which it has been designated.
         c.   No golfing shall be allowed on any portion of the park system.
         d.   No person shall engage in any activity in a rough or reckless
manner so as to endanger, injure or damage persons or property in any way.
(1996 Code § 21-1)
   B.   Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of
this section shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during which a violation occurs or
continues. (1996 Code § 21-1; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Application Of Other Regulations: All persons using facilities of
Jerseyville parks or who shall be upon the confines of such parks shall be
subject to all ordinances of the city then in effect even though the same shall
not be specifically recited herein. (1996 Code § 21-1)
8-3-2: DOLAN PARK; HOURS:
   A.   Hours Park Open: The Dolan Park shall be open between the hours of six
o'clock (6:00) A.M. until the hour of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. during Central
Standard Time and from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until the hour of eleven o'clock
(11:00) P.M. during Central Daylight Saving Time, except on such evenings when
ball games shall end later. In such event, the park shall close ten (10)
minutes after the ball field lights are turned off. (1996 Code § 21-2; amd.
2010 Code)
   B.   Prohibitions After Hours:
      1.   No one shall be permitted upon the park grounds when the park is
closed except authorized personnel.
      2.   There shall be no parking within the park after closing hours.
      3.   There shall be no loitering within the park after closing hours.
(1996 Code § 21-2)
8-3-3: CARL "JERRY" WITTMAN/LIONS CLUB PARK; PARKING:
   A.   Parking Restricted: All parking in Carl "Jerry" Wittman/Lions Club Park
and on the city property adjoining said park is hereby restricted to those
individuals using the park facilities. (Ord. 1277, 11-2-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Enforcement: Section
7-7-2 of this code, as to penalties and impoundment, shall apply to any
violation of this section. (Ord. 1277, 11-2-1999)
8-3-4: WOCK FAMILY LAKE:
   A.   Hours And Fishing Season: The Wock Family Lake shall be open to the
public from sunrise to sunset year round and open for fishing during those
hours beginning on April 1 and ending on October 31.
   B.   Fishing:
      1.   No person shall be allowed to fish at the lake without a valid
Illinois fishing license. This requirement shall not apply to children under
sixteen (16) years old or persons declared legally disabled or blind.
      2.   No person shall be allowed to have more than two (2) fishing lines
in the water at a time.
      3.   The number and size of fish that may be removed from the lake shall
be as follows:
 
Fish                   Daily Limit Minimum Size
Bluegill               10          None
Channel catfish        6           None
Largemouth bass        3           15 inches
Redear hybrid bluegill 10          None
 
      4.   No live minnow bait or fish from outside sources may be placed in
the lake without city authorization.
      5.   It shall be unlawful for any person to fish by trout line, jug, or
bank line, or to engage in frogging.
      6.   Cleaning fish on city property is prohibited.
   C.   Boats: Only boats authorized by the city shall be allowed on the lake.
   D.   Prohibited: No person shall swim, ice skate, ice fish, or walk on ice
in the lake. (Ord. 1583, 4-17-2012)
CHAPTER 4
PUBLIC LIBRARY
SECTION:
8-4-1: Library Established
8-4-2: Library Board
8-4-3: Damage To Library Property
8-4-4: Failure To Return Books
8-4-1: LIBRARY ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a free public library and reading room for the use
of the inhabitants of the city, which shall be known as the Jerseyville public
library. (1996 Code § 15.5-1)
8-4-2: LIBRARY BOARD:
The library shall be under the supervision and management of a board of nine
(9) directors to be appointed in accordance with the provisions of the statutes
of the state relating to public libraries, and said board of directors shall
have all the powers and authority covered by such statutes. (1996 Code § 15.5-
2)
8-4-3: DAMAGE TO LIBRARY PROPERTY:
Any person that shall wilfully or maliciously cut, write upon, injure, destroy,
tear or deface any book, newspaper, plate, picture, engraving, statue,
furniture, fixture, or any other property belonging to the Jerseyville public
library shall be liable for a fine of not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every
offense, said fine, when received, to be paid to the city treasurer and placed
to the credit of the library fund. (1996 Code § 15.5-3; amd. 2010 Code)
8-4-4: FAILURE TO RETURN BOOKS:
Any person who shall fail to return any book belonging to the Jerseyville
public library shall be subject to the rules and regulations as set forth by
the Jerseyville library board. (1996 Code § 15.5-4; amd. 2010 Code)
TITLE 9
WATER AND SEWER SYSTEMS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL WATER AND SEWER PROVISIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Water And Sewer Department; Superintendent Of Water And Sewers
9-1-2: Excavations For Service Lines
9-1-1: WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENT; SUPERINTENDENT OF WATER AND SEWERS:
There is hereby established the water and sewer department of the city, which
shall have jurisdiction over the water and sewerage systems, the water and
sewer maintenance and the waterworks and sewer plant of the city. The head of
the department shall be the commissioner of public health and safety. The city
engineer shall be the superintendent of water and sewers. (1996 Code § 30-16;
amd. 2010 Code)
9-1-2: EXCAVATIONS FOR SERVICE LINES 1 :
The city may require, in the discretion of the city engineer, that certain
water or sewer lines be installed only by boring underneath the city streets or
alleys. All boring shall be done under the observation of city personnel. (1996
Code § 30-1; amd. 2010 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 8, chapter 2 of this code.
CHAPTER 2
RATES, CHARGES AND FINANCES
SECTION:
9-2-1: Combined System Rates And Charges
9-2-2: Rates Established
9-2-3: Review And Notice Of Rates
9-2-4: Liability For Charges; Billing Questions And Challenges
9-2-5: Late Payments; Penalty; Discontinuance Of Service
9-2-6: Delinquent Payments; Lien Provisions
9-2-7: Turning On And Off Water
9-2-8: City Charged For Fire Hydrant Connection
9-2-9: Bond For Handling Sewerage System Funds
9-2-1: COMBINED SYSTEM RATES AND CHARGES:
The rates and charges set forth in this chapter are established for the use and
service of the combined water and sewerage systems of the city. (1996 Code §
30-44; amd. 2010 Code)
9-2-2: RATES ESTABLISHED:
   A.   User Rates:
      1.   Inside City:
         a.   For each premises which may be directly or indirectly connected
to the water lines and sewers or to either the water lines or sewers of the
water and sewerage systems, a charge shall be made for each monthly period to
be determined by applying to the total quantity of water used or consumed on
the premises during the monthly period, the rates which pertain to the use made
of the premises and the type of service received as follows:
Domestic service, commercial and industrial services: Applicable to all
premises used for either residential, commercial or industrial, including all
public buildings, cemeteries, parks, churches and clubhouses:
            (1)   Water portion of water and sewer charge.
            (2)   Water only bills.
            (3)   Sewer portion of water and sewer charge. (Ord. 1200, 3-11-
1997; amd. 2010 Code)
         b.   There shall be charged an annual fee to anyone who installs an
unmetered sprinkler system based on square footage. (Ord. 1164, 2-13-1996; amd.
2010 Code)
         c.   The city clerk shall have on file the most recent ordinance
setting forth the current charges. (2010 Code)
      2.   Outside City: For those premises which have fifty percent (50%) or
more of the improvements on the premises outside the city, the rates
established in subsection A1 of this section are increased by ordinance on file
in the city clerk's office.
   B.   Assessments:
      1.   Capital Improvement And Replacement Assessment: In addition to the
minimum monthly service charge as indicated, there shall be a capital
improvement and replacement assessment for all users of water and sewer service
as established by ordinance or resolution on file in the office of the city
clerk. The funds collected as capital improvement and replacement assessments
shall be used strictly for capital improvements and replacement.
      2.   Depreciation Fund Assessment: In addition to the minimum monthly
service charge as indicated and in addition to the capital improvement and
replacement assessment, there shall be an additional depreciation fund
assessment for all users of water and sewer service as established by ordinance
or resolution on file in the office of the city clerk. The funds collected as
depreciation fund assessment shall be maintained in a fund for replacement of
depreciable items. Said increase shall be effective as of September 1, 1993.
(1996 Code § 30-46; amd. 2010 Code)
      3.   EPA Water Testing Assessment: In addition to the minimum monthly
service charge as indicated and in addition to the capital improvement,
replacement assessment and depreciation fund assessment, there shall be an
additional EPA water testing assessment for all users of water service as
established by ordinance or resolution on file in the office of the city clerk.
The funds collected as EPA water testing assessment shall be maintained in a
fund for costs of water testing. Said increase shall be effective July 1, 1998.
(Ord. 1235, 6-2-1998; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Industrial Surcharge: There shall be an industrial surcharge as
established by ordinance or resolution on file in the office of the city clerk
to any users of the city's sewerage facilities whose wastewater discharge
strengths exceed normal domestic strength sewage. (1996 Code § 30-46; amd. 2010
Code)
9-2-3: REVIEW AND NOTICE OF RATES:
   A.   Annual Review: The adequacy of the water and sewer service charge shall
be reviewed, not less than annually, by the certified public accountants for
the city, in their annual audit report. The water and sewer service charge
shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in local capital cost or
operation, maintenance and replacement cost. (Ord. 1307, 1-11-2000; amd. 2010
Code)
   B.   Notice Of Rates: A copy of this chapter, properly certified by the
treasurer, shall be filed in the office of the county recorder of deeds and
shall be deemed notice to all applicable owners of real estate of the charges
for the water and sewerage system. (1996 Code § 30-46; amd. 2010 Code)
9-2-4: LIABILITY FOR CHARGES; BILLING QUESTIONS AND CHALLENGES:
   A.   Liability For Charges; Time Frame: The minimum charges for water
service established in this chapter shall be paid for each meter service,
beginning with the acceptance of the system by the water and sewer department
or the installation of the meter service by the water and sewer department,
whichever is the latter, even if the user uses no water during that period.
(Ord. 1253, 3-23-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Bills To All Customers: All customers with any meter readings,
regardless of monthly consumption, will be billed.
   C.   Billing Questions And Challenges:
      1.   Responsible City Officers And Personnel: Any billing questions will
go directly to the bookkeeper for answers. If not available in a reasonable
time, the problem should be directed to the city clerk. (Ord. 1253, 3-23-1999)
      2.   Challenges Of Less Than One Hundred Fifty Dollars: Any rebate for
challenges by customers of less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) must
be approved by the commissioner of public health and safety. If he is not
available, it should be referred to the commissioner of accounts and finances.
      3.   Challenges Of One Hundred Fifty Dollars Or More: If any bill of one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) or more is challenged by the customer, a
hearing must be held for a joint decision by the head bookkeeper, the
commissioner of public health and safety, the commissioner of accounts and
finances, and the mayor. Minutes of said hearing shall be taken by the city
clerk for the record.
      4.   Limitations On Authority To Adjust Bill: No one in the water and
sewer office or water and sewer department has the authority to abate any bill.
(Ord. 1253, 3-23-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
9-2-5: LATE PAYMENTS; PENALTY; DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
There shall be a ten percent (10%) charge added to each water and sewer bill,
or either, that is unpaid ten (10) days after mailing. On or about the
fifteenth of the month, the city clerk's office will mail a final delinquent
notice. If any bill remains unpaid on the twenty fifth of the month or the next
closest working day, the water and sewer department will discontinue service
without further notice. If the disconnect day falls on a Friday or the day
prior to a holiday, the disconnection will be made the day before the normal
shut off day. A further assessment as established by ordinance or resolution on
file in the office of the city clerk will be charged on any bill that remains
unpaid on the twenty fifth of the month. At this time, the landlord of rental
property will be notified that the renter is delinquent in payment of the water
and sewer bill. (Ord. 1217, 11-4-1997; amd. 2010 Code)
9-2-6: DELINQUENT PAYMENTS; LIEN PROVISIONS:
   A.   Delinquent Charges A Lien: In the event charges for any of the services
of the water and sewerage systems are not paid within thirty (30) days after a
bill therefor is rendered, the charges shall be deemed and are hereby declared
to be delinquent, and the delinquent charges shall constitute a lien on the
real estate upon or for which the service shall have been supplied. (1996 Code
§ 30-52)
   B.   Filing Lien: A sworn statement shall be filed in the office of the
county recorder of deeds by the city clerk, setting out a description of the
real estate sufficient for the identification thereof, the amount due for the
services, penalties, and recording fees, and the date when such amount became
delinquent, which shall be deemed notice of the lien for payment of the
services, penalties, and recording fees. (1996 Code § 30-52; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Foreclosure Of Lien: The city shall have the power to foreclose a lien
perfected pursuant to this chapter in like manner and with like effect as in
the foreclosure of mortgages on real estate.
   D.   Action At Law For Delinquency: The city is authorized from time to time
to sue the occupant or user of real estate in a civil action to recover money
due for water and sewerage services, plus a reasonable attorney fee for the
city attorney to be fixed by the court. If a judgment is obtained in the civil
action, the obtaining of a judgment shall operate as a release and waiver of
any lien for said amount which has been obtained, or is obtainable, under this
chapter. (1996 Code § 30-53)
9-2-7: TURNING ON AND OFF WATER:
   A.   Turn On And Off By Customer: Any individual or customer turning off or
on water at meter or shut off valve, other than city employees, will be
considered as tampering with city property and will pay a tampering fee as
established by ordinance or resolution on file in the office of the city clerk
before water is turned back on. Water turned off by the customers inside their
homes, with shut off valve after meter, is done at their discretion and does
not affect service or monthly charges.
   B.   Vacation And Emergency Turn Offs: There will be a charge as established
by ordinance or resolution on file in the office of the city clerk for
customers requesting water to be turned off when going on vacation. This is a
one time fee and will be turned back on at customer's request with no
additional charge. Turning off in an emergency, i.e., broken line or during
construction, will not be charged. (Ord. 1253, 3-23-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
9-2-8: CITY CHARGED FOR FIRE HYDRANT CONNECTION:
There shall be charged to the city and paid out of the general corporate fund
or from any other available fund other than the water and sewerage fund a sum
as established by ordinance or resolution on file in the office of the city
clerk for each fire hydrant connected to the city water system for fire
protection, which annual charge shall be paid in equal monthly installments.
(1996 Code § 30-48; amd. 2010 Code)
9-2-9: BOND FOR HANDLING SEWERAGE SYSTEM FUNDS:
Prior to the receipt of any funds that are proceeds derived either from the
sale of the city sewerage revenue bonds issued under a bond ordinance or
revenues or other monies derived from the city sewerage system, the collector
of the funds and the city treasurer, respectively, shall, for each year,
execute a bond in at least double the amount of any funds which they,
respectively, will have on hand at any one time during the year, which bonds
shall be conditioned upon a faithful accounting for such funds and shall be
subject to the approval of the city council. (1996 Code § 30-51)
ARTICLE A. WASTEWATER USER CHARGE SYSTEM
SECTION:
9-2A-1: Definitions
9-2A-2: User Charge System
9-2A-3: Arbitration Of Differences; Hearing Board
9-2A-4: EPA Access To Records
9-2A-5: Violations
9-2A-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used
in this article shall be as follows:
ACT: The clean water act, public law 95-217, as amended.
ADMINISTRATOR: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency.
BOD (DENOTING BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND): The quantity of oxygen utilized in
the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure
in five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C), expressed in milligrams
per liter.
CITY: The city of Jerseyville.
COMPATIBLE POLLUTANT: Biochemical oxygen demand, suspended solids, pH and fecal
coliform bacteria, plus additional pollutants identified in the NPDES permit.
DEBT SERVICE CHARGE: A charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost
of any bond debt to be paid by revenue generated from the operation of the
treatment works.
DEPRECIATION: The decrease in the monetary value of an asset with time.
DIRECTOR: The director of the Illinois environmental protection agency.
FEDERAL GRANT: The U.S. EPA participation in the financing of the construction
of treatment works as provided under the clean water act, public law 95-217.
HEARING BOARD: That board appointed according to provisions of section
9-2A-3 of this article.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The wastewater discharges from industrial manufacturing
processes, trade or business as distinct from their employees' domestic wastes
and wastes from sanitary conveniences.
MILLIGRAMS PER LITER: A unit of the concentration of water or wastewater
constituent. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in one thousand milliliters
(1,000 ml) of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per
million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of
water and wastewater analysis.
MULTIPLE-UNIT RESIDENCES: Shall include any number of living units under one
roof designed to house either an individual or family. Each unit may consist of
one or more rooms. Included in this classification are apartment buildings or
complexes, duplexes, condominiums, boarding houses and two-family houses.
OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE: Those actions, materials and services necessary for
the proper functioning of treatment and collection facilities over their useful
life.
ppm: Parts per million by weight.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, company, limited liability
company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate,
political subdivision, or any other legal entity or their legal
representatives, agents or assigns.
pH: The logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per
liter of solution, as outlined in "standard methods".
POPULATION EQUIVALENT: A term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or
other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is one
hundred (100) gallons of sewage per day, containing 0.17 pound of BOD and 0.22
pound of suspended solids.
PRETREATMENT: The treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction
into the wastewater treatment works.
REPLACEMENT: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories,
or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the treatment
works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were
designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes
"replacement".
RESIDENTIAL OR COMMERCIAL USER (NONINDUSTRIAL USER): Any user of the treatment
works not classified as an industrial user.
RESIDENTIAL UNIT: Any single unit of any multiple-unit residence.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwater, surface
water and groundwater are not intentionally admitted.
SEWAGE: A combination of the water carried wastes from residences, business
buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such
groundwater, surface water and stormwater as may be present.
SEWAGE TREATMENT PLANT: Any arrangement of devices and structures used for
treating sewage.
SEWAGE WORKS: All facilities for collection, pumping, treating and disposing of
sewage.
SEWER RATE: A charge for the use of and services supplied by the sewage works
of the city.
SHALL; MAY: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive.
SUPERINTENDENT: The superintendent of sewage works of the city, or his agent or
representative, or that person designated by the city to perform the duties of
that office.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS OR SS: Solids that either float on the surface of or are in
suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by
laboratory filtering.
USEFUL LIFE: The estimated period during which the treatment works will be
operated and is anticipated to exceed thirty (30) years from the date of
startup of any wastewater facilities.
USER CHARGE: A charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of
operation and maintenance, including replacement.
USER CLASS: The type of user, either "residential or commercial" or
"industrial".
WASTEWATER: The spent water of a community. From this standpoint, of course, it
may be a combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences,
commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any
groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present.
WASTEWATER FACILITIES: The structures, equipment, and processes required to
collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of
the effluent.
WASTEWATER TREATMENT WORKS: An arrangement of devices and structures for
treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge; sometimes used as synonymous
with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "sewage
treatment plant".
WATERCOURSE: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or
intermittently. (1996 Code § 30-171; amd. 2010 Code)
9-2A-2: USER CHARGE SYSTEM:
   A.   Monthly Rates And Charges: There shall be monthly rates and charges for
the use of and service supplied by the sewerage system of the city, as
established in section
9-2-2 of this chapter. (1996 Code § 30-175)
   B.   Minimum Monthly Charges; Industrial Surcharge And Additional Charges:
For the purpose of determining user charges for the use of and services
supplied by the sewerage system of the city, a minimum monthly service charge
and a service charge rate per one hundred (100) gallons of metered water use
shall be established for all users; except, that a separate charge shall be
established for unmetered users. For domestic wastes, no distinction is made
between the various classes of residential, commercial or industrial use, and
the same minimum charge and user charge rates are applicable to all classes.
However, a surcharge shall be applicable to industrial users for their
industrial wastes.
      1.   Minimum Monthly User Charge: The minimum monthly user charge shall
consist of a flat rate charge to cover debt service, fixed billing expenses,
and treatment and collection costs for the first two thousand (2,000) gallons
of water use. (1996 Code § 30-176)
      2.   User Charge Rate: The user charge rate shall be based on water usage
as recorded by water meters and/or sewage meters. It shall include amounts for
salaries, wages and benefits, operation and maintenance, equipment replacement
and debt retirement, as determined appropriate by the city. (1996 Code § 30-
176; amd. 2010 Code)
      3.   Industrial Surcharge:
         a.   An industrial surcharge in addition to the user charge rate shall
be assessed to cover the proportional cost for treatment of the additional
contaminant loading from higher strength wastes. The surcharge for BOD and SS
shall be applicable only if both of the following two (2) conditions are met:
            (1)   The concentration of BOD exceeds three hundred milligrams per
liter (300 mg/l) or suspended solids exceed three hundred ninety milligrams per
liter (390 mg/l).
            (2)   The mass loading per employee per eight (8) hour shift for
BOD exceeds 0.057 pound, or for suspended solids exceeds 0.073 pound.
         b.   If both of the above conditions are met, then the surcharge shall
apply to that portion of each parameter which exceeds the above concentration.
The city shall have the authority to assess a surcharge on any other parameter
discharged in concentrations higher than found in normal domestic sewage.
      4.   Handling And Sampling: Industrial users shall be billed an
additional charge to cover the cost of wastewater monitoring, proportionate to
the number of times per year their class of user is sampled.
      5.   Additional Charges: There shall be billed, as required, additional
charges for the following:
         a.   Actual costs incurred for user requested sampling and analyses.
         b.   Actual costs incurred for special handling or other user services
not provided for elsewhere in this article.
         c.   Actual costs incurred for handling a user's check with
insufficient funds. (1996 Code § 30-176)
   C.   Unmetered User Charges:
      1.   Single-Family Residential Users: The unmetered user charge for
single-family residential sewer users who do not have water or sewer meters
shall be approximately equal to the average monthly bill for single-family
residences unless an adjusted amount is determined to be justified based on
water usage.
      2.   Multiple-Unit Residential Users: Unmetered multiple-unit residences
shall be assessed the unmetered user charge times the number of residential
units.
      3.   Commercial Or Industrial Users: Commercial or industrial users
without meters shall have a charge established by the city on a case by case
basis.
      4.   Meter Installation: In applicable circumstances, the city or the
user may install a water or sewage meter at cost to the user. (1996 Code § 30-
177)
   D.   Review Of Charges: The city shall review the annual audit of operation,
maintenance and debt service costs for the wastewater facilities, including
sewer rates and charges, and revise sewer rates and charges periodically to
reflect actual treatment works operation and maintenance costs and the cost of
debt services. The city shall also periodically review and revise user charges
to ensure that the user charges for each user class are proportional to usage
of the wastewater facilities of the city. (1996 Code § 30-178)
9-2A-3: ARBITRATION OF DIFFERENCES; HEARING BOARD:
A hearing board shall meet as needed for arbitration of differences between the
superintendent and sewer users on matters other than billing issues concerning
interpretation and execution of the provisions of this article by the
superintendent. The cost of the arbitration will be divided equally between the
city and the sewer user. The hearing board membership shall consist of the
mayor and city council members. (1996 Code §§ 30-190, 30-191; amd. 2010 Code)
9-2A-4: EPA ACCESS TO RECORDS:
The Illinois environmental protection agency or its authorized representative
shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of the city which
are applicable to the city's system of user charges for the purpose of making
audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance
with the terms of the special and general conditions to any state or federal
grant. (1996 Code § 30-192)
9-2A-5: VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Misdemeanor Violation: Any person violating any of the provisions or
failing to comply with any of the requirements of this article shall be guilty
of a misdemeanor, punishable as a class B misdemeanor under the unified code of
corrections of Illinois 1 . (1996 Code § 30-196)
   B.   Liability To City For Costs: Any person violating any of the provisions
of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or
damage occasioned by the city, including attorney fees, by reason of such
violation. (1996 Code § 30-197)

1 1. 730 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.
CHAPTER 3
WATER SYSTEM
SECTION:

9-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
CLARIFICATION OF WORD USAGE: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissible.
FEDERAL GOVERNMENT:
Administrator: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency.
Federal Act: The federal 1996 safe drinking act amendments.
LOCAL GOVERNMENT:
Approving Authority: The city council.
City: The city of Jerseyville.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, company, limited liability
company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate,
political subdivision, or any other legal entity or their legal
representatives, agents or assigns.
STATE GOVERNMENT:
Director: The director of the Illinois environmental protection agency.
State Act: The Illinois anti-pollution bond act of 1970 1 .
State Loan: The state of Illinois participation in the financing of the
construction of waterworks as provided for by the Illinois anti-pollution bond
act and for making such loans as filed with the secretary of the state of
Illinois.
TYPES OF CHARGES:
Basic User Charge: The basic assessment levied on all users of the public water
system.
Capital Improvement Charge: A charge levied on users to improve, extend or
reconstruct the waterworks.
Debt Service Charge: The amount to be paid each billing period for payment of
interest, principal and coverage of loan, bond, etc., outstanding.
Local Capital Cost Charge: Charges for cost, other than the operation,
maintenance, and replacement cost, i.e., debt service and capital improvement
costs.
Replacement: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories
or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the works to
maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and
constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes "replacement".
Useful Life: The estimated period during which the waterworks will be operated.
User Charge: A charge levied on users of waterworks for the cost of operation,
maintenance and replacement.
Water Fund: The principal accounting designation for all revenues received in
the operation of the water system.
Water Service Charge: The charge per quarter or month levied on all users of
the water facilities. The service charge shall be computed as outlined in
chapter 2 of this title and shall consist of the total of the basic user charge
and the local capital cost charge, if applicable.
WATER AND ITS CHARACTERISTICS:
Curb Cock: A shutoff valve attached to a water service pipe from a water main
to a building installed near the curb, which is operated by a valve key to
start or stop flow in the water supply lines of a building. Also called a "curb
stop".
Easement: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
Milligrams Per Liter: A unit of concentration of water constituent. It is 0.001
gram of the constituent in one thousand milliliters (1,000 ml) of water. It has
replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is
approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water analysis.
ppm: Parts per million by weight.
pH: The logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per
liter of solution, as outlined in "standard methods".
Service Box: A valve box used with corporation or curb cock. (Ord. 1307, 1-11-
2000; amd. 2010 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 30 ILCS 405/1 et seq.
9-3-2: WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENT POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Ownership, Installation And Maintenance:
      1.   The city shall own and the water and sewer department shall install
and maintain the complete water system, water mains and service lines to the
property line of premises to be served under this chapter or to a mutually
agreed upon point, subject to the city council determining that a particular
service is economically feasible to install. (1996 Code § 30-70; amd. 2010
Code)
      2.   The water and sewer department shall furnish, install and maintain a
water meter. The shutoff valve shall be installed on the user's property line
or such other point determined by a duly authorized representative of the water
and sewer department. The water meter may be located near the shutoff valve or
within the user's premises as determined by the water and sewer department
representative. The meter and shutoff valve shall be located at a point where
it is readily accessible. (1996 Code § 30-70)
   B.   Refusal Of Service: The water and sewer department may at any time
refuse additional services to any applicant if, in the judgment of the city
council, the capacity of the system will not permit such use. (1996 Code § 30-
70; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Use Of Water On User's Premises: The water and sewer department shall
reserve the right to use the water from the user's facilities at any time
deemed necessary. No charge shall be made by the user for the use of
facilities, and no charge shall be made by the water and sewer department for
the water used by the water and sewer department. (1996 Code § 30-70)
9-3-3: AUTHORITY TO TURN ON AND OFF WATER:
It shall be unlawful, except in an emergency, for any person, other than an
authorized officer or employee of the city to turn water on or off to any
premises in the city. (1996 Code § 30-74; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-4: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE AND USER AGREEMENT REQUIRED:
   A.   City water service shall be furnished only to users upon the filing of
an application therefor and a water user's agreement with the office of the
water and sewer department, upon a form to be supplied by the water and sewer
department. However, all city water service being furnished to anyone outside
the city limits must be approved by the city council before any connection
charges are paid. (1996 Code § 30-67)
   B.   If more than one family living unit is located upon the premises, then
the user shall make an application for each family living unit, and a separate
cutoff valve, meter and service line shall be installed for each family living
unit. (1996 Code § 30-73; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-5: WATER TAPS AND FEES:
   A.   Fees Established:
      1.   Generally: The city clerk shall have on file the most recent
ordinance setting forth the current connection charges. (2010 Code)
      2.   Retap Fee: The city shall charge a property owner a fee as
established by ordinance or resolution on file in the office of the city clerk
for each retap for upgrading water services to any property. In addition, the
city shall charge the property owner the costs of materials necessary to make
the retap. (Ord. 1209, 7-15-1997; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Payment Of Fees: All water tap-on fees must be paid with the building
permit application fees for new construction, or a minimum of five (5) business
days prior to beginning construction. (Ord. 1242, 7-14-1998; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Installation Outside City: The following provisions apply to customers
outside the city limits:
      1.   The customer will dig out the location of the main line and the tap
in preparation for making the tap.
      2.   On any tap, a flat fee will be charged, plus material costs, and
construction is to be furnished by the customer. (Ord. 1189, 9-10-1996; amd.
2010 Code)
      3.   Any replacement or repair on this line will be the responsibility of
the property owner.
      4.   Any main water line installed on private property without proper
easements, that have not been accepted by the city, are the responsibility of
the property owner. (Ord. 1189, 9-10-1996)
9-3-6: DEPOSIT FOR WATER USE:
In addition to the connection charges established in this chapter, a deposit as
established by ordinance or resolution on file in the office of the city clerk
shall be made by all users requesting service in their name, whether they are
owners or renters of the property, commercial or residential users, to
guarantee payment of water bills for which the user is solely responsible. The
deposit shall be returned to the user without interest upon termination of the
water service if that user has paid all accounts in full. If the accounts are
not paid in full, the deposit will be applied to that account or any account
due in that user's name. (Ord. 1393, 1-21-2003; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-7: PERMITTED USES OF CITY WATER; RESALE PROHIBITED:
Water purchased from the water and sewer department may be used for ordinary
domestic, industrial or farm use upon the premises of the user; provided, that
no user shall resell or permit the resale of water purchased from the water and
sewer department. (1996 Code § 30-66)
9-3-8: CHANGE IN OCCUPANCY:
   A.   Notice To City Clerk: Any user requesting a termination of service
shall give written notice to the city clerk ten (10) days prior to the time
such termination of service is desired. At that time, the meter shall be read
by the water and sewer department, and the user will be billed for the charges
for water consumed. (1996 Code § 30-80; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Responsibility For Services Consumed: Responsibility for payment for
water consumed prior to the request for termination pursuant to subsection A of
this section shall be with the user.
   C.   No Charge For Change: There shall be no charge for transferring the
water service to a subsequent user. (1996 Code § 30-80)
9-3-9: SERVICE LINES:
   A.   Responsibility Of User: The user shall be responsible for the
installation and maintenance of water service lines between the curb stop/meter
and the residence or business to be served.
   B.   Mobile Home Or Manufactured Housing Parks And Multiple-Family Units:
Mobile home or manufactured housing parks, duplexes and apartment houses shall
have separate water service lines for each family living unit. In addition,
should the multiple unit, including parking and yard areas, compose more than
one lot, there shall be a separate tap-on fee assessed for each lot.
   C.   Specifications And Installation Requirements:
      1.   The service lines between the water main and the curb stop/meter
shall be at least one inch (1") in diameter and shall be installed at a minimum
depth of thirty six inches (36"). The service lines shall be constructed of
either soft copper type K or type L.
      2.   A water service line from the curb stop/meter to the building shall
be as in subsection C1 of this section or one inch (1") minimum copper tube
size HDPE class 200, shall meet all requirements of the state department of
public health, and shall have no. 12 THHN tracer wire with four feet (4') of
wire coiled in the pit.
      3.   Service lines shall not be covered until they are inspected and
approved by a duly authorized water and sewer department representative. (1996
Code § 30-72; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-10: METER INSTALLATION; SWIMMING POOLS:
   A.   A user of city water shall permit the water meter to be located upon
his property. (1996 Code § 30-76)
   B.   In order for a property owner to be charged for water only that is used
to fill a swimming pool with no corresponding sewer charge, it will be
necessary to install a separate meter at the expense of the property owner.
(1996 Code § 30-68; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-11: EASEMENTS:
A user of city water shall give such easements and rights of way as are
necessary to the water and sewer department and shall allow access for the
purpose of construction, repair, maintenance and meter reading of the water
system. The necessity shall be determined by the commissioner of public health
and safety. (1996 Code § 30-77; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-12: EXTENSION OF MAINS:
   A.   Determination Of Necessity And Responsibility For Costs:
      1.   The city council shall first determine if an extension of a water
main is economically feasible based on the estimated costs of the extension and
the number of existing potential users that will use water along the extension.
      2.   If the extension is economically feasible, the water and sewer
department may install and pay the cost of the extension at the discretion of
the city council.
      3.   If the city council elects not to pay the cost of extending the
water main, then the person desiring city water service may install the
extension at his own expense upon written consent by the city council, and said
person may request a recapture agreement for his expenses, which agreement the
city council may approve solely in their discretion.
      4.   The city council is not required to pay for any extension to an
undeveloped area or to any area, such as a subdivision, being developed unless
there are sufficient existing residences or businesses to make the extension
economically feasible.
   B.   Extension By Other Than Water And Sewer Department:
      1.   The water and sewer department shall approve all plans and
specifications for any extension.
      2.   Before any extensions are installed, the plans and specifications
shall be reviewed and approved by the city council prior to approval by the
Illinois environmental protection agency.
      3.   Ownership of the water main extension and right of way easements as
are necessary shall be conveyed to the city for all extensions installed by any
person other than the water and sewer department. The water and sewer
department shall maintain the mains thereafter.
      4.   No water main extension will be permitted if, in the opinion of the
city council, the system does not have the necessary capacity to serve the
proposed extension. (1996 Code § 30-78; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-13: USE OF GROUNDWATER AS POTABLE WATER PROHIBITED:
   A.   Definitions:
    PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, company, limited
liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust,
estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity or their legal
representatives, agents or assigns.
   POTABLE WATER: Any water used for human or domestic consumption, including,
but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes,
or preparing food. (Ord. 1433, 3-30-2004; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Prohibitions: Except for such uses or methods in existence before the
effective date hereof, the use or attempt to use as a potable water supply
groundwater from within the corporate limits of the city by the installation or
drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited. (Ord. 1433, 3-
30-2004)
   C.   Penalties: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be
subject to a fine of up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
violation. (Ord. 1433, 3-30-2004; amd. 2010 Code)
   D.   Memorandum Of Understanding With EPA: The mayor is hereby authorized
and directed to enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Illinois
environmental protection agency (Illinois EPA) in which the city assumes
responsibility for tracking remediated sites, notifying the Illinois EPA of
changes to this section, and taking certain precautions when siting public
potable water supply wells. (Ord. 1433, 3-30-2004)
9-3-14: CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL:
   A.   Cross Connections Prohibited: A user of city water shall not connect
any water service line or any plumbing connected with the service line to any
other water source. (1996 Code § 30-75)
   B.   Cross Connection Control Program:
      1.   Program Adopted: The cross connection control regulations set out in
the ordinance codified herein are hereby adopted and enacted as the cross
connection control program of the city. (Ord. 1228, 5-5-1998; amd. 2010 Code)
      2.   Amendments To Program: Any and all additions or amendments to such
cross connection control program, when passed in such form as to indicate the
intention of the city council to make the same a part thereof, shall be deemed
to be incorporated in such program so that reference to the cross connection
control program of the city shall be understood and intended to include such
additions and amendments.
      3.   Copy On File: A copy of such cross connection control program shall
be kept on file in the office of the city clerk, preserved in looseleaf form.
It shall be the express duty of the city clerk or someone authorized by said
clerk to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances which
indicate the intention of the city council to make the same a part of such
program when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to
extract from such program all provisions which may from time to time be
repealed by the city council. The copy of such program shall be available for
all persons desiring to examine the same and shall be considered the official
"cross connection control program of Jerseyville, Illinois". (Ord. 1228, 5-5-
1998)
      4.   Penalty: Any violation of the program shall be punishable by a fine
of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day a violation of
any provision of the program or of any ordinance shall continue shall
constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 1228, 5-5-1998; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-15: TAMPERING WITH, DAMAGE TO SYSTEM:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper, adjust, damage or in any
manner interfere with the components or operation of the water system owned by
the city. The penalty for tampering, damaging, adjusting or in any manner
interfering with the components or operation of the city water system shall be
up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), payable to the water and sewer
department.
   B.   If the penalty imposed by subsection A of this section is not paid
within thirty (30) days after the amount is determined, the water and sewer
department shall shut off the water service. The amount of the penalty shall be
determined by the city council.
   C.   In addition to the penalty under subsection A of this section, a user
responsible for damages shall reimburse the water and sewer department for the
actual cost of repairing any damage arising from a malicious act or tampering.
   D.   Users shall report any known evidence of tampering, adjusting, damaging
or interfering with the operation of the water system, owned by the city, to
any member of the water and sewer department or the city council.
   E.   Any malicious act or damage to the water system that is not
appropriately punishable by this section shall be prosecuted under section
1-4-1 of this code. (1996 Code § 30-81; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-16: NONLIABILITY OF CITY FOR INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE:
All water service supplied by the water and sewer department shall be upon the
express condition that the water and sewer department shall not be liable, nor
shall any claim be made against it, for damages or injury caused by reason of
shutting off of water for repair, relocation or expansion of any part of the
system, or for the failure of any part of the water system, or for
concentration of water for such purposes as firefighting, or the restricted use
of water. (1996 Code § 30-71)
9-3-17: MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS:
   A.   Unlawful Grounding Of Electrical Equipment To Water Lines: All new
electric services and/or any additional service to those now existing shall be
grounded to a driven ground. It shall be unlawful for any person to ground
electric equipment to water lines owned by the city. (1996 Code § 30-2)
   B.   Fluoridation Of Water Authorized: Until further directions are given by
the city council, the water and sewer department is authorized and directed to
provide the means and to proceed with the introduction of approximately 1.0 to
1.5 parts per million of fluorine to the water being distributed in the water
system of the city. (1996 Code § 30-65; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Backhoe Width For Excavations: It shall be unlawful for any person
excavating in any city street for any water main to use a backhoe over twenty
four inches (24") in width. (1996 Code § 30-79; amd. 2010 Code)
9-3-18: ARBITRATION OF DIFFERENCES; HEARING BOARD:
A hearing board shall meet as needed for arbitration of difference between the
superintendent and water users on matters concerning interpretation and
execution of the provisions of this chapter by the superintendent. The cost of
the arbitration will be divided equally between the city and the water user.
The hearing board membership shall consist of the mayor and city council
members. (Ord. 1307, 1-11-2000)
